div.p: THE WRANGLING LOVERS: OR, THE Invisible Mistress. A Comedy. As it is now Acted at the Dukes-Theatre.
LONDON, Printed for William Crook at the Sign of the Green Dragon without Temple-Bar. 1677.

body.head: THE WRANGLING LOVERS: OR THE Invisible Mistress.

div.head: ACT. I.
SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: SO, I am first at the place appointed. I had lost my honour, if the fair Inviter, that sent me the challenge, had got into the field before me.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Sir— with your mouth wide open as if you were coming to eat me.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I have more stomach to sleep than to eat.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Sluggish Brute cannot you watch one night without all this yawning and rubbing your eyes.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p:
These signs are the Language of Nature, by which she declares her wants. Draw but the Teat from the mouth of a Babe, and still the lips retain a pretty sucking motion, which tels us with a silent sort of Oratory, that it is still a hungry. Nature even in the most vile sort of Animals will not without
complaints be denyed her due refections. I think Sir, it is as natural to sleep as to eat.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Yes to such Sots as you it is natural to do nothing else but sleep and eat. You slept enough, if snoring be a sign of sleeping.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: A little towards morning, when I had no more paper left to burn under my Nose.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: If your loud snoring had not waken'd me your sitting up all night, had been to much purpose, instead of your calling me, I was fain to call you, half a dozen kicks could scarcely rouze you.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I think you did ill to treat a servant so, that does your business as well sleeping as waking. I knew my faculty, and therefore had no scruple of Conscience to take a nap contrary to your commands.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I have helpt you to an excuse for your negligence, but you had best not let me catch you napping so any more.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: The next time you have an occasion to rise early, let me but lie in your Antichamber upon a pallad Bed, and you will find you have a Servant more advantageous for the design of waking you, than a Cock, or an Alarum-Clock.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: And keep me awake all night with a noise more ungrateful than a Catterwailing:

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: There's not a man in all Toledo sleeps with the like decorum. I have a clear Conscience, and my sleeps are harmonious.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Go, leave rubbing your eies and look about, if you see e'r a Lady entring the Church give me notice.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Of all my Senses that of Seeing at present is most imperfect, I can scarcely hold my eies open, they twinkle like a couple of rush lights.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: You Snail Beetle mend your pace, How like a Carriers horse you go Nod, Nod along.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p:
Well if he takes up the trade of being a Lover, I'le lay down that of Vallet; for Lovers are alwayes thus chollerick, and I shall have but a Spaniels life on't, lie down at his Chamber door a nights, and in the morning rise and shake my ears, and all the day after be set a rangeing, or be bid to
fetch and carry; O the wicked cause of all these evils is at hand.— Sir, Sir, look to your self, here comes a couple of dark Lanthorns towards us.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Begone, keep your distance.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Iacinta, go and stand Centry at the Church door, and if you see my Brother coming give me notice.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: The hour of his devotions is not yet come.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: I listened at his Chamber, as I came down stairs, and I heard him stirring.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: My diligence shall secure you from a surprise.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: How excellent is her shape, and her meine how graceful.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Don Gusman, for so I know you are called, tho you are ignorant both of my name and Quality, tell me with what sentiments do you receive a visit from a Lady, that thus exposes her honour to your censure.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: With all the faith, sence, and honour, that a true Cavileer ought, who is thought worthy to be trusted, and so highly honour'd by a Lady.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Did not the Letter I sent you yesterday with a summons to meet an unknown person much surprise you?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I was surpris'd to think, that you would trust your person with me here, that in your Letter durst not trust me with your name.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Do you think you know me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I am sure I do not, for if I did, you would then know me, of which I find the contrary.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I am sure I do not, for if I did, you would then know me, of which I find the contrary.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: I call'd you by your name.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: But, Madam, did you know me, you would in your Letter have intrusted me with your name, and here with a sight of your person. Whilst you keep your Vail on, I am sure you don't know me as you ought.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: I confess Sir, what I have done proceeds not from my knowledge, but from my belief of your gallantry, and you may hope much when my faith is confirm'd by experience.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p:
I hope Love will inspire you with a quick faith, to believe that if you should discover to me all those glorious charms
you are enrich'd with, that I should be capable of conserving a sufficient Empire o're my self, and to remember what I am obliged to render to so great a merit as yours.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: If I find you as discreet, as I think you gallant, I shall have a very great inclination to acknowledge the trouble I have given you.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I am resolved, how great so e're my passion is, my respect shall be inseparable.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Though you wonder, yet blame not my denial. A proceedure so new as this, seems to have something in it inexcusable, but when you shall learn, what at present I must not acquaint you with, you will then at least not condemn it: all that I can now say to you is, That the liberty I take ought not to make you think any thing to my disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I would not press you to enlarge your favours; but that I know the discovery of your person will give me yet more advantageous thoughts of you.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: I am of some Quality, and without vanity I will say, I have attractions enough to engage you to more than you think, if it were permitted me to shew you them. But I have reasons not to be subverted, that now make me conceal my self from your sight. Desist from further expectations till time has convinced me, that I may with assurance trust you with the sight and knowledge of my person.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Will you have the cruelty to raise me to this high expectation, and leave me here to be tortured by imagination?

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: I will unvail my self if you have the injustice to demand it, but then I will for ever withdraw from your sight; this day past you shall never see me more.

div.stage: Elvira puls off her glove to turn up her Vail.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p:
Hold, yet now I see your hand uncovered, it appears so fine, I am more desirous and impatient to behold the rest. By that little patern I perceive the whole piece is excellent, Madam I must acknowledge I should be transported to see you, if you had that indulgent goodness to suffer it. But since you have reasons to the contrary, I ought to have some too not to desire it, but rather accommode my self to what is your pleasure
to prescribe, than let you grant, what I had the insolence to press you to.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Madam, Don Ruis is at the further end of the Street, and comes towards the Church.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Sir, I must leave you at present, but by your respect to me, and the honour of a Cavileer, I charge you not to follow me one step, nor cause me to be followed by any, for besides that your curiosity would be vain, I would never more converse with you.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: What assurance do you give me that you ever will again, or how distant is that happy minute from this hour?

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: I will half an hour hence meet you in this very place, and tell you when and where you shall see me next.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: In this half hour consider you have drawn me to the rack, and leave me there upon the full streach, and resolve to have the charity to ease my pain, by the shortness of your delay, Think, one that has had a glimpse of Heaven how wrapt he is with desires to have a full view of its glories.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: So much as you abound in virtuous sentiments, and so punctual as I find you to my commands I will endeavour to have thoughts of you, that shall not displease you, Adieu.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.p: So 'tis even as I thought, one assignation begets another, this night will be a Vigil too: and so it will go on night after night, till at last I run mad for want of sleep.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.p: I was thinking, that Lovers are very vertuous people, for they in one months intrigue keep more Vigils, than are found in the Churches Kalender for a whole year.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Leave your Meditations, Rascal.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.p: Here comes your Friend and Hoste Don Ruis.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: If she should return sooner than I expect, and find company here, I might lose the happyness of conversing a second time with a person, whose short absence I already think too long, and with impatience wish the sight of.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Don Gusman good morrow to you, you are got early to your Devotions— I was no sooner up, but I came into your apartment, and knock'd at your chamber door, and my Servants told me you went out at break of day.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I had some thoughts in my mind that broke my repose, and therefore got up early, that I might be so sleepy at night, that no disquiet of mind, may then hinder me from taking my rest.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Don Gusman put not on these disguises before your Friend, if it be inconvenient for me to know your secrets, I will not press you to a discovery, but your early rising this morning I know was design; for hearing a noise last night, I rose, and looking into your Anti-chamber, I saw Sanco sit nodding with his head in the Chimney, and hold smoking paper under his nose to keep him awake: I doubt not but in order to obey your commands of calling you early this morning. I then ghess'd at the design, and retir'd to my bed without taking further notice, and your early going abroad this morning, has confirm'd the truth of my suspitions.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I must own you were not mistaken, yet in justification of what I told you, I will acquaint you with the cause whence those thoughts did proceed, which broke the soundness of my sleep.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: If you doubt my friendship, or think I want the faculty to conceal, what you are about to entrust to my knowledge, yet forbear the discovery: I assure you I am not at all curious.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Nor do I wrong your friendship with such suspitions. I must draw him from this ground, and the relati. aside. on of what is already pass'd affords me a pretence. If you'll defer your devotions we will take a turn in the Cloysters, and I will there give you a short relation of no unpleasant adventure.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I am glad you do not repent your early rising.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p:
As yet I have no cause.— Sanco be vigilant, and if you discover the vail'd Lady or her attendant coming, step to the Cloyster door and becken me, I'le have my eie still this
way.— Be sure you let 'em not depart till I have first spoken with 'em.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If once they come within my Gripe I'le be sure of them.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Except to call me, stir not a foot from this place.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No Sir, I will set my self down at the foot of this Pillar, and be as immovable till you return. Gus. Ruis exeunt. This Don Ruis I hold to be a man of much greater discreetion than my Don Gusman. He never gets up by the same light that he goes to bed, but is so good a Husband as to save candle in the morning, and let the Sun light him to find his cloaths, and who indeed woud spend money to see to dress himself, when he may have day light for nothing. Well, I will fall to my devotions to pass away the time▪

div.stage: Sanco puts on his Masters cloak, and sits down with his beads in his hand, and falls a sleep.
Enter Elvira, Jacinta vail'd, at the other side of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: We'll leave the Church with what speed we can.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Madam, let not fear discompose you, tho Don Ruis and he are walk'd aside, their discourse may not be about you.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know he is acquainting him with what is pass'd.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I look on Don Gusman to be more discreet than to trust affairs of this nature to the knowledge of any.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: I believe he would not, if he could reveal to him a Ladies name, but if relating only the business, my Brothers curiosity should lead him to be an eye witness of our second interview, and place himself, where, unseen, he may behold what manner of person I am, he may ghess by my motion, or actions, or stature: I will not expose my self to the danger of being known.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: See, yonder sits Sanco devoutly a sleep, wrapt in his Masters cloak, shall I wake him? you may with him leave directions for an after meeting.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: No. I will be gone without saying any thing.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Don Gusman will stay expecting your return.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p:
I will make him wait unprofitably, to punish the
indiscreetion, which I know him guilty of.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: It is but your suspition Madam.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Being my Brothers Ghest, I can at any time retrieve this omission, by letting you in disguise meet him in the Street with directions, as I did yesterday for this appointment. Come.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Farewel most pious drowsie Sanco.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: So, my Friend has left me for his devotions. Where's Sanco. Ha, the Rogue's fallen fast a sleep with his beads in his hand, and my cloak about his shoulders, rouze, rouze, Animal. kicks Sanco. The beast snorts on, if your Nose and Ears are set fast on your head, I'le make use of 'em to raise you up by.

div.stage: Gusman puls Sanco up by the Nose and Ears, who makes a noise.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Au, auh, auh—

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Hold your bellowing Beast.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir, wont you let a Man alone at his prayers?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: At his prayers Rascal, do you say your prayers like English Phanaticks through the Nose? must the Church be your dormitary, and my cloak your covering? if I find it any more about your villanous shoulders, I'le pin it to your back with a Toledo bodkin.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I thought, Sir, a good Christian, tho a poor Devil, was not so despicable, but that he might serve for a peg to hang your cloak on.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Has the Lady or any from her been here since I went?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No Sir no—

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: No Sir, I may as well ask the pillars; you was at your devotions in a heavenly trance.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay Sir, but I saw no female visions.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Which way went the Lady? when she parted from us?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I thought it was forbidden to look after her.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Why did I let her go? why did I not follow her? to be so easily perswaded to quit her, will make her think I had no value for her, and then she will leave me to my dispair and ignorance.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Did you lend her any mony?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Lend her mony, Rascal.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nay if you did not, you'l see her again for certain. I'le pawn my life she comes again, and layes the foundation of a better acquaintance, by asking to borrow a purse of gold.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Scoundrel, she is of Quality.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Yes Sir, most women that make assignations, have that good Quality.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Her own tongue declar'd she was no mean person.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I'le as soon take a Jocky's word of his horse, or a Poet's of his own play, as a womans of her self.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Her Garb was rich and Noble.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No question but it was the gift of some such noble person as your selfe.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Her mein and behaviour shew'd her of breeding, her shape was Charming, her wit was great, and no question but what she conceales, is not less beautiful and surprising; slave, if you had had any wit, or minded your Masters interest, you might have discourst the woman whilst I was talking to the Mistress, and have given her occasion to let fall some word, that might a little have contributed to the discovery of what I now remain ignorant.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: A wise man never makes a puther▪ when reason tells him tis unnecessary and surperfluous, no doubt but the Lady you commend, has as many good thoughts of you; thinks you are as handsome and comely a person as walks the streets of Toledo, And judges no less by your embroder'd suits and change of rich apparel (which you shift oftener than the Major Domo of his Majesty) that you are too of Quality, but with more reason; and from thence too imagins, that you treat nobly all the Amorettos that you keep; and intends, I warrant you, that you shall be the cheif of her Dons.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Hold your poltry tongue, Rogue, if you were worth my trouble of chastiseing I shoud now give your insolence severe correction, if hereafter you do not speak with more respect of the most virtuous person in the world, I shall lay a side all considerations, and put you in a condition of never more sullying a Ladyes reputation with that stincking breath of yours.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I acknowledge I am not worth your trouble of chastiseing, and it is to profane your noble hand to let it fal on any part of me but you'd let me have the priviledge of speaking two or three words; I wou'd demand, in what particular you find this person so virtuous; what virtue is there in appointing a Love embassadress, to stand century, who imagining that she has found her Cully, gives an assignation by break of day the the next morning; when all the virtuous people that I know are at that time, as I us'd to be, fast a sleep.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Yes persons of your sanctity snore out the time that such well dispos'd Virgins spend at their devotions, I believe it her practice to be here thus early, especially on such great holy dayes as these.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: A Very godly practise, to make the Church a place of Rendevouze for Love affairs.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Did not the place protect thee, these provocations added to thy negligence wou'd not let my anger be appeas'd without thy life.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I shall love a Church the better for it as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I know by her not coming, that she was here in my absence, when thou wast sottishly a sleep. Ile search round the Church for her, and then if I find her not, resolve to leave the place.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: You will do more discreetly, Sir, for it is time to go to breakfast.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: But I shall do more discreetly, for your sloath and carelesness to turn you out of my service; give me my cloak: fare you well. unless by some means or other you can find what is become of the person I have lost the sight of by your Rascally negligence, never more come near me, unless it be to send your brutish soul on an Errand to the Devill.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: So, this it is to be subservient to a Love Adventurer, if his Mistress quarrells with him, he quarrells with his man; if she turns off the Master, the Master turns away his servant. O instability of humane life; well, Ile ferret every altar in the Church for her, and enquire at every house in Toledo but Ile find her. And if I meet her, Ile have her to him, tho it be on pick-pack.

div.stage: Enter Don Ruis, Beatrice following him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Sir, Don Ruis.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Beatrice! is the Adorable Octavia here Beatrice!

sp.speaker: Beat
sp.p: Yes Sir, she is at her prayers. I saw you pass by the altar, and stole from behind her, to tell you so.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I thank thee kind Beatrice, will she be displeas'd think'st thou if I approach her?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Sir! 'twill but insense her, the league was never so strong as now, betwixt my Mistress and Don Diego. they are now never from one another, they can't say their prayers asunder, and I believe shortly they won't be able to sleep asunder.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: The last time I saw thee thou told'st me of their often quarreling.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yes Sir, they fall out every day still, and jangle like bells on a holy day; they are as Jealous of one another, as the old Count her father is of his honour; they are ever a scanning punctillios, so that the least occasion begetts a falling out on either side. And now and then I put in an unlucky word, for your advantage.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.p: Continue thy kindness, were it not for thee, I should quite dispair. I made my applications to Count- de-Benevent her father, and he having first approv'd of Don Diego's addresses to the fair Octavia, denyes the least overture of mine. And unless he quite break off, I must languish out my life in the tortures of a succesless Rival, and a dispairing Lover.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: The mischeif on't is, there is a kind of sympathy, or instinct, or I don't know what in their love, that like a worme cut asunder, it still joynes together again; but Ile do my best Sir, and when ever their falling out may be to your advantage, Ile be sure to give you notice, your servant Sir. I dare not stay any Longer.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I'le follow you at distance. Whilst the fair Octavia pays her devotions to heaven, I'le pay mine to her, my sighs shall be as fervent as those she sends up her petitions in: nor shall her eyes look more devoutly upward, than mine shall do at her.

div.stage: Whilst she with zeal does heavens indulgence move, From her I'le draw compassion by my Love.

div.head: ACT. II.
SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene, the Street before Count Benevents House.
Enter Octavia, Beatrice vail'd, Sanco following them.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: HEark you, pretty Female.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I don't know you.

sp.speaker: San,
sp.p: Nor I whether you are pretty, but my Master has infected me with his implicite faith, and because he believes your Mistress handsome, unsight, unseen, I must of consequence, as I am of his Retinue, vouch the same of you.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What's your business?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Is not your Mistress an unreasonable woman to make a young Gentleman to rise at break of day to meet her, and then to pop him off with so short a visit; to leave him without shewing him her face: to say she'd come again within half an hour, and to break her promise and ne'r go near him since? I wonder how she can go to her prayers in a morning and have no better a Conscience.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: My Lady is not a person that makes appointments.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: You may well be asham'd on't, and so may she too.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I would fain know what your Mistress's meaning was, to set you last night at the corner of a Street, angling for my Master with the enticing bait of an amorous assignation, and when you might have got him by the gills, forsook the sport? If she had had a mind to be acquainted with his good parts, it had been but unvailing, and if he had lik'd the Frontispiece, he soon would have made his Entrance into the main building.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Friend, if you are drunk it is not my fault, as for my part I am tir'd with your sottish discourse; Stand away.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: One word more.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: How now Friend! how came you so well acquainted with my Woman?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I am yet no better acquainted with her than my Master is with you: and as he is desirous of a better correspondence with you, so am I of a little more intimacy with her.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Friend, you had best leave us, and go about your business.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: As a true Servant I must do my Masters business First I am his Ambassador, and must not depart without you first give me Audience.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Friend, you'l endanger a Bastinade.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: That usage to an Ambassador is against the Law of Nations.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: But you come more like a Spy, and as a Spy you shall be received, if you have yet the boldness to proceed in your impertinence, till you arrive at that door there.

div.stage: Sanco stop: they go forward to their House.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: The truth is, not having my Credentials about me, I shall appear rather a Spy than an Ambassadour. I will take their advice, and keep my distance. I have no great stock of valour to repel dangers; therefore I will make use of my discretion, and like a wise man keep out of harms way— Auh, they are gone in, by their threatnings that must be the place of their abode: and I'le wait here about awhile to see if they don't take harbour here to shake me off. If that be their design, they'l come forth again presently.

div.stage: Enter Ordgano, looking at a distance upon Sanco.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Ha—! Sure I am not mistaken!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What's he a Spy too? He comes to take a survey of my Body, and as the Academist said when he hang'd the Butchers great Dog, He shall see it in it's full dimensions.

div.stage: Sanco streaches himself at his full length.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Now, who does he take me for?

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Country! How dost do Country?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I know not whether I am your Country or no: but I don't remember I ever saw you in mine.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: O Heavens, I'le not believe you have so disobliging a memory.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: It may be it is because I am fasting.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: I'le give you a Breakfast for old acquaintance sake.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: It may be then I may remember you better. But I can't stir from hence yet.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: 'Tis so, he's upon design.— Well, I'le step in here and bid 'em bring us a Morsel of something. I'le be with you presently.

div.stage: Exit. Ordg. into Don Diego's House.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: At least I shall remember him hence forward, that his acquaintance came so luckily. For I am heartily an hungry. I wish he knows me but well enough to come again according to his promise.

div.stage: Ordgano re-enters with Eggs and bread.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Come Country, will you sup off a couple of raw Eggs?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: That's the Fashion of my Country.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: That's lucky. Ay I know it well: here's a piece of good Bread and Garlick too, and that's the fashion of your Country too, is it not?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: O yes! in our Country we are as great lovers of Garlick, as any Country in Spain.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Come Sir, the Boy is bringing some wine: in the mean time I will sup off an Egg to your good health.

div.stage: Enter Boy with two Bottles of wine.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I thank you Signieur, and I'le pledge you.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Come Country, here's some wine for you, Country.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Gratias Signieur; Now I am sure of the Wine, I'le venture to see if he has ever been of my acquaintance. Signieur the more I look on you, the less I remember you.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: O, and that be all you'l remember me anon.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Of what Country are you?

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Of your Country.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What of Aragonia?

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Now 'tis out. Yes, I am an Aragonian.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: So far he's right. What may your name be?

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Why have you forgotten my name too?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I don't remember I ever knew it.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Bless me what has happen'd to you! Can you remember your own name?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: You can't. Let's hear.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sanco.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Sanco, that's right. I durst have laid a wager that forgetting my name you could not have remembred your own. But Signieur Sanco I find I was mistaken. Come my service to you Signieur Sanco. drinks.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: He knows Argonia is my Country, and my name Sanco, he has formerly known me, tho I have forgotten him.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Come pledge me, Signior Sanco, then sup off t'other egg Each sups off his egg So. This is usually my Breakfast, a raw Egg and a glass of Malago.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay, good hearty meat, but it is no great filler of the Belly.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: A good preparative for dinner.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: This is no more to my belly, than I was to the Church I left just now.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Come Sir, I am glad to see you with all my heart. I am rejoyced I meet you in a time of leasure, when we are not constrain'd to salute one another, with a bare scrape of the leg onely. I don't love old Acquaintance should meet and part with dry lips, and so your good health once more.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: You are one of the most hearty and most cordial persons, that I have ever met with, and your civility will never let me forget you hereafter. And so I drink off the rest of my Wine, to your good health, and our better acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ordg,
sp.p: Off with it ' drinks. So now my dear Sanco tell me, what inchantment confines you to this place. I find by the glances of your eye upon that part of the Street, you are upon some design.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: It is a matter of no small consequence.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: If I can be any thing serviceable to you in the business, let me know it, and for the honour of our Country, I'le shew the best of my skill.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I have been only dogging a Lady, and her Attendant to their home.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: And they went into that House I warrant you, which you lear'd at so often since we have been here.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Very true. And I stand to watch if they come out again.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Umh, have you any Letter or Message to deliver to 'em.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If they stay long there, then I conclude that is their place of Habitation.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: A very rational conclusion. I find you a man of judgment, and very expert in managing a Love intrigue. Is it not some such business Country: ha! let me by way of divertisement partake a little more knowledge of the business.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Why, you must know that I am of the retinue to Don Gusman.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: A very fine person, tho a little chollerick when he is cross'd in love.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Is he in love them? with whom?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: You shall hear: last night a cunning love factress, that very well understood her trade, as my Master was coming home to his lodging, meets him at the turning of a street, pretty near the house of Don Ruis de Moncade, who is Don Gusmans friend, and whose ghest my master is at present.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: In this rancounter he received an appointment to meet an unknown Lady, early this morning, at the Church of St. Dominick.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Very pretty, so.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p:
We obeyed the summons, the Lady came punctually to her assignation, but after a few Ceremonies, and a little pritle pratle on both sides, the Lady withdrew, promising to
return within halfe an hour, the time expir'd, Don Gusman waited out his patience, the party expected came not again, Don Gusman not knowing her name, nor where to find her, sent me in quest of her: at last I spy'd her coming out of the Church, and have now set her.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: And here she hous'd. So.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Now my next business is to acquaint my Master with my success.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: So. I am glad matters succeed so well; and since your affairs require not my service, I will content my selfe with the hopes of a future occasion, and at present detain you no longer in prejudice to Don Gusman, to whom this news must needs be wellcome.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Adios, Signior.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Adieu, Sancho.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Ordgano, well performed.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Coud you hear perfectly Sir from your window?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I heard all, and am amaz'd at her infidelity. Love was never declar'd in more kind and obliging expressions, than I receiv'd from her last night at parting. I'le give her a visit whilst my rage is arm'd with scorn, and upbraid her with her dissimulation, and ungrateful infidelity.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady spy'd you from her window, and sent me to tell you, that she is coming down into the court to speak to you.

div.stage: Don Diego, Beatrice in the Court before the House.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Your Looks Don Diego, tell me my invitation is not pleasing to you, what is the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: If nothing be the matter, you don't do discreetly to come abroad when you are in such an ill humour as this, and incommode persons who are no wayes oblig'd to remove it.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I know it very well Madam, I might not it may be have been troublesome to you, had you not sent me an invitation.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Beatrice, prithee tell him, that the door he came in at is still open.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: And let her tell me too, that it was open this morning by break of day to let you out.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Who are you acquainted with, that cou'd so quickly inform you, that I went out so early?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: So early Madam! You did go out then I perceive, since you demand who coud inform me.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Yes, I did go out, but from hence forward I will not with so great tranquility take the pleasure I receiv'd this morning. I shall continually imagine I see you, or some of your Spyes set to give you an account of my actions.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: No, all that you can do for the future, shall be indifferent to me, I shall abandon your Empire with a facility, that shall sufficiently discover, your chains are not so difficult to be broken, as your vanity does make you believe.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I find you very full of temerity in presuming to say you abandon me. You, whom I have so often ordain'd never to see me more, but have no sooner banisht you my presence, but I have seen you at my feet, imploring my grace, and making use of all your entreaties, to incline me to repeal the sentence, and declar'd that you could not without death obey: if my chains, as you scornfully say, are so easie to be broken, why have you not done it twenty times before? either they are more powerfull than your malice will allow, or you are a very weak man, Don Diego.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: You have sometimes driven me from you, but 'twas when you were sure that I would return again; of which you were glad, as appears by your frequent revoking those commands.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: You are not the first troublesome companion, that has been received out of respect to good manners, and whom one sees with regret.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p:
But I will no more, Madam, be that troublesome person. I will have the honour now to quit you, and do let you
know, before I take my leave of you, that it is to be for ever; and that your lingring in the Church longer as you have formerly done, expecting that I should come and make my addresses to you, will now signifie nothing, and if I go or come by your house, or stand still near it, it shall not be out of design that you should send Beatrice to invite me in.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: And I would have you know, that I will never go to Church hereafter, but with my Father, in whose presence you dare not, unless I please, say the least thing to me; and that you shall, if you have a fancy for it, walk in sight of my window, a thousand times in a day; and I not take the least notice of you. If I look out and smile, interpret it not kindness, but in derision of your folly. And since you are so kind to promise me never to come here again, I will be so civil to dismiss you now without further ceremony, and deal really with you, and let you know, I wish with all my heart that you were already gone.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: You do assure it me with an indifference too great to make me in the least doubt of what you say; in what I spake, there was something I know not what of passionate, which sufficiently discovers, if you had a mind to observe it, that I love you still, though you deserve it not: But the cruel indifference that you have now shewn, makes it plainly appear, you never had any true love for me; and so Madam I'le be preparing to take my leave. Beatrice, prithee give me a glass of your fair water. Beat. Exit. So, now Madam— Don Diego walks about pulling on his gloves with difficulty, and when the water comes, one half on, which he puls off to receive the glass. Drinks. Gives Beatrice the glass, and then puls on his glove again. Lingers out time in stroking them on.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Well Sir—

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: You don't hinder me from going.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Do your pleasure—

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p:
You do well, the trouble would be in vain, and to shew you it would, I bid you adieu, and declare it not to be
as formerly, an adieu Iusqú au revoir, such as I have taken till this present, but an adieu for ever. Your Servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Beatrice he's gone.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Did you observe how he spun out the time, in hopes you would change your mind.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: But after all, can my going out to the Bath so early this morning be the onely occasion of this Quarrel? He cannot sure, at a thing so customary, be thus offended.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: See, he is come again—

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Beatrice, I had forgotten to take my leave of you. There's some duccates for you, it may be they may be as lucky to you as Don Ruis's, or those Don Gusman rewarded you with this morning for your early rising. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I find by his last words, there is something which we don't understand, run Beatrice, and call him back.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: If'twas to me, I'de e'ne let him go.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I must clear it, it may be some thing offensive to my honour: Run.

sp.speaker: Benev.
sp.p: within. Odsprecious where are you here, hoy—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Madam, your Father is come in at the back door, I hear him rage.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! There must be some other ground of this quarrel by his naming of Don Gusman; what it can be, or who this Don Gusman is I cannot imagine.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You have not leasure now to examine it.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Once again I'le see Don Diego, to convince his mistakes, and rectifie his opinion of my reputation. That done, I'le never see him more.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay Sir, we are right, this is their cage, here they hopp'd in.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: The House is very remarkable.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If you have but patience to walk here a little, we shall see the canary Birds percht up in their window anon.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Here is no glimpse of'em: We'l view the windows on this other side of the house.

div.stage: Enter Elvira, Jacinta: their vails turn'd up.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: We'l keep at this distance.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: If we stand here we can't lose sight of 'em: here we may see all up that Street.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The sudden resolution of my Brother was very lucky to our present design; I should else have been puzled to have invented a pretence to go abroad just at this time of the day.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: What was his reason at first to conceal you from Don Guzman? and e're since he came to be his Ghest, to confine you to the back apartment of his house, and tell him you are out of town?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: For fear any thing should be discours'd to my prejudice, if it was known that Don Gusman had a lodging so near me. Have you still sight of 'em Iacinta?

sp.speaker: Iao.
sp.p: Yes Madam, the House must be hereabouts that they look for, by their hankering so. But Madam, the same reason continuing still, why does Don Ruis now order you to go to your Aunts, and to come home to his House in her Coach an hour hence; as if you were just come out of the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I objected the same, when I received his orders. And he told me that was but a pretended reason. And that the true ground of my concealment was, that he had information there would be some Overtures of a marriage with me, made to him by Don Francisco de Medina; of whose Revenue my Brother is a greater admirer than ever I shoud have been of his Person. And that some dayes since he heard his Applications are elsewhere, and his affections deeply engag'd.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: That no doubt is the true reason.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
And since the, friendship betwixt my Brother and Don Gusman is much increas'd. My Brother has acquainted him with the love of Octavia: that Don Diego is his Rival, and that his pretentions are rewarded with the favours which his fidelity more justly merits. Don Gusman on the other side has
given him a relation of our assignation, and what pass'd this morning; of Sanco's success in pursuit of the vail'd Lady; and of his present coming abroad with design to walk under the window. All this my Brother told me, to let me see the difference, betwixt my manner of living, and that of many other Ladies, who hazard the honour of their Families, by the indiscreet liberty they take, and applauds the Life I lead, ascribing all to his care, and conduct of me.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I wonder who this blundring Sanco has by mistake followed instead of us.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Who e're it be, she lives hereabouts. See, they come this way again.

div.stage: Pull down their vails o're their faces.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I believe they are at a loss.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Let us meet 'em Iacinta.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: They have sight of us.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: See Sanco! we are staring up at the windows, and the persons we look for are here in the Street.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay, here they are. They spy'd you from their windows, and are come down to you. So there's the inviting dop for you. They curtesie to Gusman, he goes to Elvira.
When a Woman likes her man, she has an Eye like a Hawk: She'l spy him twelve score off. And if she don't care for him, she's so blind, she can't see him, though his mustachoes brush her Nose.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Madam, thus unexpectedly to surprise me with your presence, was the only way you had to make amends for your breach of promise to me this morning.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, I came not now to make excuses for my self, but to complain of you. If I have broke my word it is by your example, and my not coming to you was your own fault.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p:
How Madam, is it possible? That I, who waited with a burning desire of seeing you again, should be the occasion of your not coming, which is the thing I now lament of. I am confounded to think how you should be worse than
your word by the example of one, who so exactly kept his.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I have evidence enough to justifie my complaint.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: If it be not a disparagement to seek a witness in a Servant, Sanco can testifie how diligent I was not to miss your return.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Yes, my Master set a Memorandum on my nose and ears.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I stir'd not from the place, but out of design to remove a Freind, whose presence, I fear'd, might interrupt your coming. But my Servant I planted there all the while to give me notice of your first approach. But if your finding him a sleep, as I did, has been the occasion; I revoke my act of mercy, and declare his fault unpardonable.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: To render my self more intelligible, know that it is not of his neglect of duty, or your want of diligence that I complain, but of your indiscretion; the greatest fault a Cavalier can be guilty of, is to publish the favours he receives from persons of our Sex. I perceive by the colour that now rises in your face, that you already understand my meaning.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Your Eyes, whose transcendant brightness easily penetrates the thickness of that vail which covers them, are witnesses too illustrious not to be believ'd. I confess I made a Friend my Confident, a Friend that till now I ever found discreet. but by what you inform me, I discover how much a Captive he is to you, and that the Empire you have over him has made his love do violence to his friendship.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You take me then to be the Mistress of your Freind.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Yes Madam, I take you to be Octavia de Pimentel, whom Don Ruis adores. And now I begin to lose the hopes I had conceiv'd. For how adorable soever you be, love ought not to make me undertake any thing to the prejudice of my Friend. Rather than add to the number of his Rivals by offering you my heart, I ought to lend him the assistance of my Sword to remove them he already has.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I do know Octavia, but I am not her.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p:
If you are not her, I ought then to have a quarrel with Don Ruis; who by divulging the secret, is guilty of a crime,
which nothing, but the interest of a Mistress could have render'd excusable.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Don Ruis is the best Friend you have. He told this to a person who hath given him as many proofs of fidelity, as you e'r receiv'd from him, and intended you no more harm in communicating it to that party, than you did me, when you related it to him.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: If he has discours'd it to one only, and that person be yourself, I cannot but be of opinion that you are his Mistress, if you are not her, do me the grace for one moment, to grant me the sight of those many charms your cruel vail robs me of. I shall then know if my friendship be inconsistent with the love my heart is going to be possest with.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Do you know Octavia?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Don Ruis often has shew'd me her picture, which out of devotion to her, he constantly wears about him: do not refuse me the happiness of being in a capacity to adore you without inquietude.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You desire a thing, that is not fit for me to grant, till I have had a sufficient proof of your discretion. It may be if I had told you my name before, or shew'd you my face, you had then too reveal'd one, and describ'd the other. No, my reputation is a thing that well deserves the best of my care with whom I entrust it. I'le see you again, as soon as I may safely tell you whom I am.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Leave me not without some further assurances that I shall again be thus blest, and that e're long I shall see you in the full lustre of your charms.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Nothing shall hinder it, if to Don Ruis you do not again reveal what is past.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Stay, and I'le make you vows.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: If you have any thing more to say, follow me to the Church of that Covent, and there discourse it.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Sanco there are four pistols; Gives Sanco money. See if you can make her earn it by discovering any thing to the advantage of my design.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p:
I'le warrant you, I'le open her mouth with this bunch of golden Keyes. Money will set a womans clack a going presently.
Nay heark you, tho my Master and your Mistress are gone aside, it is not come to that yet, 'twixt you and I. I have not made my compliments to you yet.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I doubt your compliments will not be worth staying to hear.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I have a very good one in store for you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I question it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: But you'l like it.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Don't let it be too long then.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: There 'tis for you, gives her two pieces of Gold. without saying a word to you. How do you like it?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I doubt 'tis a second hand one.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: But 'tis ne're the worse for wearing.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: It is a dry compliment.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: But such a one as you can't well answer, unless you repeat part of the same to me again.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I'le assure you I would not have receiv'd it, but that the money of Persons of Quality was alwayes lucky to me, and for lucks sake I'le keep it all.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Then for lucks sake I'le keep the other half.
sp.stage: Sanco puts the rest in his pocket.
sp.p: You see Don Gusman is a man that knows how to return affronts in the best manner. He had not offended you thus if you had not first affronted me this morning, by scorning to take notice of me, when I dogg'd you and your Mistress home from Church.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I'le persue the hint, I may learn something to my Mistresses advantage. Aside I had not been so uncivil, but that my Mistress gave me the Nod.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I began to think I had been deceiv'd, when she ask'd me how I came acquainted with you, and threatn'd so. She dissembled so cunningly, one would have thought her really angry.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: She did indeed counterfeit rarely well.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Seeing her so very angry, I ghess'd she was near home, and then press'd no further.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: And did you see us go in?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Yes, and went presently and fetch'd my Master to shew him your house; and see if we could catch you peeping out of your windows.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: And which are our windows now, think you?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: There's your door, and there's your windows.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: O cunning Sanco!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What are you my Country too?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: How your Country?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: That you know my name so readily. I never told it you.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I know it well enough.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: But now, for the two Pistols I have given you, I would have you te'l me one thing, which I don't as yet know, and that is your Mistress's name.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: I must needs beg your pardon. My mouth is seal'd up.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: But with a Wafer.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: So strong, that all your Art can't force it open▪

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: You have very strong jawes, if gold can't open 'em.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Not at this time.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If your legs have the same faculty as your lips, you'l die a Maid, Sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: That which is in hand has no force with me, it may be the assurance of as much more to come may prevail.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: These Women are devilish pick-pockets. Now must I produce the other two. 'Tis e'ne true as you said, those pieces will be lucky to you. They already draw as many more to 'em. Look you here, will you open?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Give 'em me.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Unravel then.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I will not tell you her name, because I am sworn to the contrary, but give 'em me, and I'le tell you how you shall know it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: There. Now if you'l but return me half of 'em back, I will tell you the names of all the Kindred my Master has, since his great Grandfather, and the Lord knows how much further.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Take notice, what I shall tell you is for your sake, and not for the gold.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Then give me that back again.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: The kindness I shall do you in giving you an occasion to get into the affections of your Master, who has set you about this work, will be a sufficient benefit to you.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nay I knew that mony thrown into the Sea, is as soon to be gotten again, as when 'tis given to a Woman.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: In short Sanco, if you woud know her name, go to the neighbours houses, where you saw her go in, and I warrant you, they'l tell you that, and all else you have a mind to know.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I might have thought of that my self, and have sav'd the mony.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: My Mistress and Don Gusman are come out of the Church, and are just upon parting; for your ears, and the sake of your dear Mustachoes, Sanco, never discover it was I that put you into the way of coming to the knowledge of us.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No, No.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Adieu.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: So, I have handsomely wheadled her, I think.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Well, how have you dispos'd of my Gold?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I'le assure you, Sir, I gave 'em her every one. You'd a sworn, if you had but seen how she then carried her self, that I had given her some offence, and had she not bethought her self that the mony of Persons of Quality is very lucky to her, she'd have done me the affront to have refus'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: What have you discover'd?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nothing Sir for sake of your gold, she had sworn secresie, but for my sake she told me, if I'd but enquire of the Neighbours, I might know both her and her Mistress's Christen names, Sirnames, Quality, Condition, and what ever, I had a mind too.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I'le satisfie my curiosity with all expedition.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Here comes one has the countenance of an Informer.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Hark you, Friend.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Your Worships most humble—

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Are you an Inhabitant hereabouts?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: At your service Sir.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: who lives here in this House?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Certainly Sir you are one that has not liv'd long in Toledo, that you are ignorant who that house belongs to.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Prithee to▪ whom does it belong to?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: To as worthy and gallant a Person as— this day is in all Spain, the King excepted.

sp.speaker: Gus
sp.p: I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: He is a little hot and hasty, old and testy, but he lives not that has no fault.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: How he racks me with delay. But I ask thee what his name is?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Lord Sir you are much of his temper, you are the most impatient'st Gentleman. Why Sir, that is the house of the Count de-Benevent!

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: The Count de-Benevent.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and to let you see, that I know what I say, his name of baptism is Alfonso. His sirname de Pimentel. Benevent is the name of a Country, that brings him in twenty seven thousand, nine hundred sixty and fourteen duccates yearly Revenue. Where he has not only jurisdiction over his Vassals and Tenants for the preservation and recovery of his Signieural Duties, but has also arbitrary power in all causes Criminal, except high Treason. As for the Children he is blest with, he has onely one Daughter, call'd Octavia, to whom Don Diego de Stuniga, Grand Alguazil to his Majesty, and Don Ruis de Moncade, make their Addresses: and Beatrice is the name of her Woman, who is as inseparable from her, as- as- as Sir any thing you can imagine.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Stop thy Alarm, eternal Babler.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p:
Lord Sir, if you had but let me have told you that I saw 'em go out early this morning together, and that they came
home together, not half an hour ago, so closely vail'd that the Devil himself would have been plaguily puzl'd to have known 'em, and- and- and- I had done Sir.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Then begon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: The Devil go with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Hark you friend, of what Trade are you?

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: An Apothecary Signeor.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I thought so, you talk'd so like a Fool.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: All circumstances agree to confirm me this was Octavia▪ this is her Father's House, she went out this morning, return'd an hour ago, my Servant follow'd her, and here she went in. I must now in right to friendship, cruelly stifle my birth of passion, slight her endearments, refuse her appointments, and shun the Caresses of a person, I find so obliging, and believe so excellent.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir, here comes Don Ruis.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Walk this way to avoid giving him suspition, that I have had any commerce with Octavia, Sirrah, leave your learing up at those windows.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: O Sir, my neck is stiff, I can't so much as turn my head that way,

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Don Gusman, which way lyes your business at present?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I was going home, in hopes to meet you there.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I'le bear you company, word was brought me just now that my sister Elvira is come to town.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: You tell me surprising news.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I expected her coming, but was not certain this wou'd be the Day of her arrival.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I have heard she is a great beauty.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Her vertue is greater than her beauty.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: She is then an admirable Creature, for I have heard very great commendation of her beauty.

div.stage: Beatrice above at the Window make a sign to Ruis and withdraws.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p:
Ha- Beatrice has given me the sign out of the Window,
This is the house of the Count Benevent. Let me desire you to walk slowly forward, she is coming down to speak to me. I'le o're take you at the end of the street.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I hope she has not sent her maid down to discover what she commanded me to conceal.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: O Sir, I have had a great mind to speak with you. There has been a great falling out just now betwixt my Mistress and your Rival. They are parted in anger, never to see one another more; this is the most favourable time that can be, to insinuate your self into her heart, you are already in her esteem, she has an opinion of you to be a Gallant man and she is one that cannot be long without a Gallant, and no doubt will sooner make choice of you than another. Adieu Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Stay Beatrice, and take my thanks a long with you.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I shall be hang'd if I am seen.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: How kind was fortune to direct me here to receive this good news.

lg.l: Lovers whom fate does so severely treat.
When they receive small favours think'em great.

div.head: ACT. III.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Don Ruis, Don Gusman, Elvira, unvail'd.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I Hope, Madam, you will be more favourable to a stranger, than to believe all that Don Ruis has told of me, to be truth.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: It is so probable, that I can't i' th' least doubt it.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p:
Believe it rather his rallery, or that I only entrusted
him with an imaginary secret, to oblige him not to conceal from me all the true adventures that have hapn'd to him.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: No, Don Gusman, she knows my way of rallery with my friends, is to surprise 'em with the discovery of such harmless truths as these.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You are a Cavalier so accomplish'd, that I question whether there is e're a considerable fortune in all Toledo that shuns you. And I shoud be more surpris'd to hear that you had no Mistress, in this short time you have been here, than I am now, to understand that you have one.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: You may easily imagine what sentiments one can have for an invisible beauty.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I cannot imagine your motive to dissemble it. Since Love is the most innocent diversion, and the sittest imployment for so Gallant a person.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: It is the policy of a well bred Cavalier, in the presence of a Lady, never to own his Love to another.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Sir, a Woman in a vail came just now to enquire for you, her earnestness to speak with you, made me imagine her business of importance, wherefore I brought her to the gate of the Walks, where she waits to see you.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Don Gusman, I'le wait on you presently.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Is it Sir, as my Brother says, that you disown your Love for this vail'd Lady, out of Galantry to me, or are you really not in Love.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I believe my self never to have been a Lover? But since I have had the honour of seeing you.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: If I had thought to have procur'd to my self this declaration, I would not have complemented you upon the good fortune that has happen'd to you. Tho you woud not have me believe the last you met with. Yet your answer shews that you are too gallant not to be very happy.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I must never own a happiness from Love, till you believe your self the author of that happiness.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
I am not so great an Enemy to my own repose to endeavour
a conquest, which will not be in my power long to maintain. And I woud little esteem the submissions of a heart so slippery as yours.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Do you think, Madam, that one can get out of your Chains, as easily as he is fetter'd with em? and that it is possible for a heart to resume its Liberty, after it has given it self up to so great a merit.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You have said as much to the obliging person that charm'd you last, and yet you wou'd be unfaithful to her, if you cou'd but find but any body to bestow that heart on which you wou'd take away from her.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: If she would have unvail'd, and I had found her face answerable to her shape, mein, and wit; this sally of my heart could not have been without injustice, but now having seen you before her, your charms have not given me the liberty to wait till she shews me hers, and if now I had the weakness to change, I shoud not be unfaithful to Her, but to you.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I find, Don Gusman by his Wit has been conversant in all the gallantryes where ever he came. Tho I had the better cause, yet he still got the advantage on his side. to Ruis

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I am sorry I missed the pleasure of your discourse, but now Elvira, whilst you renew your acquaintance with the other Walks of the Garden, which since you have been absent have received great alterations. I will consult with Don Gusman in a small affair of my own. Elv. Jac. Exeunt. Beatrice, from whom I receiv'd the good news I acquainted you with, has been with me again, to tell me what haste then made her forget. That to morrow is her Mistresses anniversary birth day. And councels me to make an open profession of my Love to Octavia in the gallantry of a serenade to night under her Window, according to the custome of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I advise you to persue the hint.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: In order to it I entreat from you the composition, of a Song whist I go and provide for the dance.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: It wou'd now be injurious to your affairs to plead insufficiency, I will rather expose my ignorance than seem to want a will to serve you.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I'le leave you here to the performance of what you undertake.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: At your return you shall receive the fruits of my Meditation.

div.stage: Gusman walks about as if he studied.
Enter Elvira, Jacinta vail'd, Don Diego persuing them.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Madam, it is in vain to shun me, where ever you Retire I'le persue you, speak to you, and upbraid you.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: How Sir! persue her! speak to her! and upbraid her! In the presence of Don Gusman de Haro no Lady shall ever receive such affronts. And to this I'le not permit the thousandth part of that insolence.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Tho she flies to my new Rival for protection, I will even in thy presence tell her, that she is a faithless woman; and on thee, that art the cause and author of her Infidelity, I will revenge it.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Iac. Ah, ah, ah

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: My Friend engag'd against my Rival. Hold, hold. They leave fighting. Don Gusman you must not take up my quarrel, it is my right to fight him. He is my Rival.

div.stage: Ruis offers to fight Don Diego.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: But in my presence he offer'd the affront to her, and it is my right.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Hold, if he has affronted her I have a double right, yours is but single, therefore you must Offers to fight thrusting Gusman aside. give way.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I'le not quit my claim.

div.stage: They are struggling which shall fight with Don Diego.
Enter Count de Benevent, starts, and draws his Sword.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ha! Ods precious. Ods, ods amongst Cavaliers. Come, here's an old Cock of the Game at time of need will come in for a sparring blow with ye.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Sir, I except against your sword, in respect of your Age.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: And I must not engage mine in your defence that are the Parent of the fair Octavia, whose beauty renders her the Idol of my soul. Therefore we must defer our quarrel till some other time.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Don Ruis the word of a Cavalier ought to be inviolate, Ods precious, did I not promise you, on condition there might arise no quarrels betwixt you and Don Diego, that if he withdrew his pretentations to my Daughter, I wou'd next approve of yours, and yet you in prejudice of your word now take up the unjust quarrel of a Rival.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Sir, the Punctilio of this quarrel is an affront offer'd my Sister in presence of my friend. Her outcryes call'd me to her assistance.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: He would press on her retirement.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Hau Don Diego, here arises another Punctilio. And you and I shall come roundly to't anon. Do you, Don Diego, before you have quitted your pretentions to my Daughter, make addresses to another. Ods precious, Don Diego.

div.stage: Stroaks up his Mustachoes and Struts.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Sir, run not on in this mistake. I thought the person I persu'd had been the fair Octavia, and not his sister.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: There's my Punctilio gone agen. Ods precious, but how do I know this to be truth.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Your Daughter and I parted in anger, and having notice given me she was in the Walks, I resolv'd to come and make my submissions. When I enter'd the Garden, seeing that Lady pull down her Veil and retire from me as I came towards her, made me think 'twas she, and her haste to shun me confirm'd me beyond doubt. I follow'd her with resolutions not to leave her till she had had heard me speak. This I hope Sir, makes my peace with you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Live Don Diego, long grow your Mustachoes. Ods precious, Cavaliers mistakes are no Punctilioes you must be friends.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Madam, I beg your pardon, and yours Sir, to Gus. And yours Don Ruis, for this error to the fair Elvira. But in the concern of Rival, to all I walk upright.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, he's in th' right, there's the Punctilio on his side.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, I own it as your mistake and forgive it. to Don Diego. And I know Don Gusman is so gallant, by following it to justifie my example.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I acknowledge Don Diego brave.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, and so he is, and you Don Ruis shall have no farther resentments.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I have forgotten it already.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: By my Grandsire's soul and these Mustachoes, thou art a gallant fellow too. Ods precious, Don Diego, you and I will go together.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I'de be content to have a Rancountre ev'ry day for the diversion of so pleasant a reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: This Count Benevent is a very worthy person. But the testyest little old gray-beard in all Spain.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I never met with such a hot spur, his humour is very pleasant.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Brother, I will cross the Walks, and make a visit to some Nuns of my acquaintance, in the Convent that joyns to the Garden.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: A Discreet Maid is always Mistress of her self. Elv. Ja▪ Exeunt. Now I'le persue my design.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: And I'le retire to a more private Walk.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You see Sir, how subject we are to mistakes. And one error still begets another.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: But I am not yet convinc'd that your going out so early was to the bath, or only thither. For the Vallet of Don Gusman, who follow'd you from the Church of St. Dominic, has discover'd an adventure which it may be was not less pleasing to you than the other.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I heard him babble indeed, and perceiv'd by his discourse that he was run into a mistake. Which occasion'd that in you, which made such a hurly burly in your brains. And I hate you so much for believing me guilty of what that Sot kept a prating, that all your endeavours and acknowledgements shall never perfect a reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: You ought without difficulty to excuse a jealousie occasion'd by such convincing circumstances.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Convincing! Did he tell you my name? or if he had, I'le own no Lover but him, that will give the lye to a thousand witnesses, when I am tax'd. No Pretender to me shall dare believe any thing but his own eyes. And not all they inform him neither.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: A Love like mine, cannot but be subject to jealousie. What is so dearly priz'd, we are ever in fear to lose. Put your self wholly into my possession, that I may no longer be tormented with the fears of being depriv'd of you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: No, Don Diego, now you can no longer boast of your deserting me, I'le depart with the honour of having left you; and whilst I may, March off with flying colours.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Yet a few minutes stay.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: No, I will not endanger the loss of a triumph, of which I am now certain.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: You know not the outrages of dispair.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I know my own resolutions.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: And I mine,

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Adieu Don Diego. Turns back.

You don't hinder me then from going? You would Ironicaly. not let me go, but that you know I'le return again. But think not I bid you adieu, as formerly for a short time only. I bid you for ever adieu.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Had you been a perfect Lover, you cou'd not have become so absolute a Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Come, come, come Octavia, Ods precious to morrow is a new day, fidle, fadle comes twice in a Moon. To be thus late a broad is no good punctilio in a Woman. Ods precious it grows late. Don Diego fare you well.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: She resolves to maintain her conquest, along as I did mine. But I perceive she durst not stay, fearing 〈◊〉 hearts revolt, yet e're I sleep, tho night comes on a pace, I'le make some progress towards a peace.

lg.l: If e're like mine a Love she entertain'd.
Sh' already gives the conquest she has gain'd.

div.stage: Enter Gusman reading in a Tablet. Sanco.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Auh! he's here: That such a gallant Person as my Master should turn Ballad Maker, and that Don Ruis should have such a crochet in's pate to sing'em! How strangely we commence our degrees in Love. First it makes us Fools, then Mad-men, then Poets, and our Wives as fast as we marry make us Monsters, and then, like commencing Doctors, we wear the Badge of our Occupations.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir, Don Ruis sent me to you for some Stanza's. I believe he meant a Ballad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gus
sp.p: Do you think so Sir. There. Gus. gives the Tablet to Sanco. Give that to him, and tell him, I composed them to the Tune that he is so much pleas'd with. Make haste.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay Sir.

div.stage: Enter Jacinta veil'd, pulls Gusman by the Sleeve as he is going off.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Sir, Sir.

div.stage: Jacinta gives a Tablet book to Gusman, he opens it and reads.

sp.speaker: Gus.

body.p: Sir, I will not fail to meet you to morrow at the same Church, where we made our first appointment, and at the same hour I will appear unveil'd, ambitious to subdue your heart, that the Glory of so noble a Conquest may add to the triumphs of my Eyes.

sp.p: I am still of opinion that I receive these invitations from the Mistress of my Friend: hearing of our quarrel, she had the knowledge of my being here. Since I have seen the Charms of the Fair Elvira, I can at least with more ease be just to my Friend. I will return my answer in writing on the other side of the Leaf. Gus. writes in the Tablet.
So! Return that to the Lady. Gus. exit.

div.stage: Enter Elvira, turns up her Veil as she enters.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Give it me Iacinta, I have an impatient desire to know his answer. Elvira takes the Tablet and reads.

Madam, my passions are grown so extream violent, since last I had the honour to discourse with you, that I find it will not be safe trusting your self with me. For should you give denial to
my request, how extravagant soever, I should attempt something in prejudice of your honour and my own. Therefore whilst I am yet capable of respect, I request you not to come in my way. For this reason I refuse to meet you, and beseech you not to honour me any further than with your esteem. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: O Iacinta he knows my heart already. This answer is pen'd word for word to my desires. I fear'd the declaration of his love had been but expressions of gallantry, but this refusal to meet his veild unknown, gives me at once a proof both of his love and constancy.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: In this trial you dangerously expos'd the quiet of your mind, tho not love, yet curiosity might have led him to a further progress in this adventure.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Great gains are not purchas'd without great hazards. Come, I can now without fear let loose my heart, and give it a full range in the walks of love.

lg.l: 'Till we have proof a Lover will be just
Our satisfactions lessen'd by mistrust.

div.stage: Enter Don Diego, Ordgano with their Swords in their hands. Flambeaux, and Musick: the Musick is plac'd under Octavia 's Window.
The Scene changes to the Street before Count Benevents House.

lg.l: HE's a flegmatick Lover
In whom we discover
A temper that never do's change,
A Breast that like mine with jealousie burns,
Now Love and now Anger possess it by turns.
With fears I grow wild, and with hopes I grow tame.
That passion is weak, that is always the same.
With fears, &c.
That Passion, &c.
But the sanguine brisk Lover
Can never give over.
He cannot be dully at rest.
He knows that her charms have conquer'd yet more,
That many there are, who do sigh and adore.
He trusts not to merit to give him success,
For women love only by fancy and guess.
Or if to desert by great chance they prove kind,
The Fair still are fickle, and oft change their mind.
Oh the starts of a Lover
Do plainly discover
The passion he feels is extream!
For he that loves well, and does not possess,
Must either be jealous, or else love you less.
Then say not my fears, or my doubts do you wrong,
He cannot be quiet, who's passion is strong.
Small fires but glow, and are alwayes the same,
But the greater will rage, and will scatter their flame.

div.stage: The Song ended a Cerebrand is danc'd: as the dance ends, musick is heard without.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Heark.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: More Musick! put out your Lights, and range your selves under the window.

div.stage: Enter Don Ruis, Sanco in cloaks with Swords in their hands. Flambeux, Musitianers, Dancers.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Pass.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Play musick.

sp.speaker: Deig.
sp.p: Guards.

div.stage: The lights and Musick of both run away: they clash in the dark, lose one another, Don Ruis, Ordgano, fight retreating. Sanco stands mufl'd in's cloak, trembling and poaking all the while with his Sword in his Scabbard.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: They have quitted their Station. Who's there?

div.stage: Ruis returning touches Sanco with his Sword.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Sanco.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Don Ruis. O Sir, are you alive?

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: And so art thou.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Aye Sir, and as whole as a Fish. A pox on't, I could not get my Sword out.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: We have made them quit their post.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay Sir, We are Masters of the field.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Run after the lights and Musick, and bid 'em turn again.

div.stage: Sanco goes to the other side of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: This must be Don Diego, upon the same design.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Here, here, the days our own. Come again Cowards, come again.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Do you see 'em?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: They were all yonder in the next Porch, they are coming Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: In order-Musick begin.-

lg.l: AH Celia, what powerful charms have you,
That with a look coud so my heart subdue?
And at first sight impose a Law on me;
Against my fundamental liberty?
I look'd, and Lov'd! O! fatal was that day!
I look'd, until I look'd my heart away.
I look'd, and lov'd, &c.
I look'd until, &c.
And yet upon your brow you wore a frown,
What would sereneness then, and smiles have done?
In vain▪ in vain, we boast a free born Soul,
When Beauty can so easily controul;
When every glance does liberty expose,
And with a look we native freedome lose.
When every, &c.
And with, &c.
You bid me now resume my liberty,
Alas I cannot, if I wou'd be free:
Should Fate the unwish'd power bestow, yet still,
Having that power I should want the will.
Where Love so absolute a Monarch reigns,
They court their fetters, and grow proud of Chains.
Since you with scorn and frowns can conquer so,
Ah try what Miracles your smiles wou'd do.

div.stage: At the end of the dance enter Diego, Ordgano, and more Servants, all with their Swords and lights.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Fall on.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Stand to your Arms.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: So we have regain'd the field.

div.stage: Enter Count de Benevent with a sword in his hand, in a Cap and Night Gown, and his Mustachoes in a Case and Servants with Lights.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, Don Diego, I approve not these nocturnal follies, why must I be alarm'd out of my Bed, and the whole neighbourhood be disturb'd? Ods precious, Don Diego.

div.stage: Octa. Beat. above at the Window.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Pray hear me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Ods precious, Don Diego, I tell you 'tis no good punctilio to proclaim my Daughter to the whole town, by your tenebrious
exploits. Ods precious, I like not she shou'd be made the subject of publick discourse.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon that—

sp.speaker: Ben.
