sp.p: Ods precious, pardon's an Ass, and I ride my Mule. Don Diego this punctilio quadrate's with my judgment, you must pretend no more to my Daughter; ne're more come near my House. Ods precious, if I catch you within my Doors 'twill be an affront to my Mustachoes, farewel Sir.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What, that I'le tell a Lye: Ods precious such another hope, and you and I will crack a punctilio together.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Now he's he gone in Madam.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Don Diego, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: 'Tis no hard thing to ghess the matter when Rivals meet.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I hope you have not reciev'd harm.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I doubt not but your hopes are as obliging to my new Rival, that gave you this cerenade. I question not but you'l be glad of so fair a pretence as the authority of a father to justifie your forsaking me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Well Don Diego—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Well Don Diego. Ods precious but I say 'tis not well

sp.speaker: Don Diego.
sp.p: You shall find it ill done Don Diego, ah. Ben. draws upon Don Diego, who retreates only defending himself. There's a Punctilio for him, now I shall exchange another with you, Mistress Mag-pye, that are chattering above, and change your Cage for you. Ods precious, Girls talking gibberish out at a Window.

lg.l: Women in Love count these things peccadilloes;
But, Ods precious I'le make her mind her punctilio's.

div.head: ACT. IV.
SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene; the Street before Count de Benevents House.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: SAnco walk in sight of that window, and if you see e're a Woman look out, shew her that Note, and becken her down to receive it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: How then Sir?

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: She will return an answer either in writing or by word of mouth: mind what she sayes to you, and bring me an exact account.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I know Sir, it is not manners to question our betters. But it is so material, when one is to deliver an answer, to know where you will be.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: You shall find me here in the Church, with your Master and Elvira.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: But Sir, not knowing me, suppose she shou'd refuse to come down.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: It is because you are not known here that I ask'd Don Gusman leave to imply you in this affair. I would otherwise have entrusted it with one of my own servants.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir, I am known here.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Thou known here Sanco? how came your acquaintance and with whom.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I had like to have made a discovery. Why Sir, ever since last night that I was here with you. No doubt they took notice of me out at Window.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: No, 'twas dark, and you had a cloak on, they'l not know you again.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir, I must beg leave to be once more unmannerly. Pray Sir, here being no superscription upon this Note, what is the name of the person to whom I am to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p:
Her Name is Beatrice, she is servant to the Lady
whom we Cerenaded last Night.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Cerenade ay, you shall Cerenade by your self next time. Love gallanties were never fortunate to me.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: If any one of Count de Benevents house, question you, say you are Kinsman to Beatrice.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I can tell that lye without scruple, for she and I are brother and sister by occupation.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Be sure you forget not one syllable of her answer.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Look you Sir, I'le be picking my ears all the while I am here Eves dropping; that I may the better hear every word she sayes.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: So, now go forward.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Little thinks Don Ruis, how well I am acquainted with Beatrice, if I had unluckily discover'd my Masters mornings ramble, and his Mistress early devotion, I should have set the devil upon his Gallop indeed. The door opens- I'le abscond.

div.stage: Enter as out of his house into the street, Count de-Benevent, Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, Pedro, how thou hast, put my Cloak on.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I'le mend it Sir▪

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, a new Cloak want mending.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Set it right, I meant Sir.

div.stage: Pedro goes to make his Cloak hang right and touches his his ruff. Benev. falls a jumping.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: O Sant Iago! Sant Iago! Thou disorderest my Ruff. Ods precious varlet am I to see the King in a rumpl'd Ruff.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sir now it is well.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods Precious well, when I say it is ill, art thou upon thy Punctilio's with me. looks on his Watch. Ods Precious. 'tis almost nine a Clock. Come, Come, he that will thrive at Court must rise betimes. Dios nos guarda.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p:
What a testy old Wasp was this, I'de sooner be valet to his Mule, and venture to have my brains courteously knock'd out with a compliment, when he's so civil to make legs backward, than walk behind him, whilst he has that long sting at his tayl.
But now the Weezel's gone, methinks the Rabbets shou'd be peeping out of their boroughs, Auh, I see that which I look for: mumping already, ist- ist- Beatrice looks out at Window. Sanco shews the Letter. She curtesies, nods, claps to the window. Auh, there's the courteous dop, and the significant Nod, she's gone from the window and is coming down to me. I'le go into the Court and meet her.

sp.speaker: Dieg
sp.p: Ha! There's that Fellow again upon some design. I'le follow him.

sp.speaker: Beat:
sp.p: Well Sir! what have you to say to me now.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nothing not I. There

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Let it speak for himself.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: From whom comes it?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Read and learn.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You are very short.—

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: And you very inquisitive.—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: It behoves me to ask.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: And me to say nothing.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I'le try to hear their discourse stipes behind 'em.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: But I'le first know from whom it comes before I bestow the pains to read it.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.p: I was commanded to deliver it barely and simply to you. And will not go beyond my order, there if you will take it you may.

div.stage: Diego steals behinde Sanco, and snatches the Letter from him.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: If you wont, here's one that will.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: He chop'd as sure as a Dog at a Shoulder of Mutton.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I'le read it without so much ceremony.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir, you are a very courteous Person, and now I have delivered it safe into your hands, I'le take my leave.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Stay Friend, till I have read it, it may require an answer.
sp.stage: Diego treads on Sanco's foot whilst he reads the Letter, who is often itching to be gone.

body.p:
I have followed your counsel and what ever advantage
Don Diego pretends to have had in the Rancountre. Yet be assur'd, tho overpower'd by his numbers, I retreated more like a respectful Lover, than a cowardly Rival; make haste to let me profit by his misfortunes, and fail not to acquaint me with what happen'd after I withdrew.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Now it will do you no further service, Sir, be pleas'd to return it to me again.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: No Sir, but I'le be so civil to my Rival to pay Portage.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: O hold, hold Sir, hold, hold, I am satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: But I am not satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Hold Sir, I will give you what satisfaction you please.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Ah you Coward! What do you wear a Sword for?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Hold your tongue Huswife, or I'le, have you up before the Inquisition for provoking me to wrath.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Away you Sot.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I have been at my Prayers this Morning, I do the work of a good Christian, bear afflictions patiently; besides I have such a respect for so brave a Cavalier, that if it be for his satisfaction, he shall beat me twice as much.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I beat you less for your own sake, for undertaking this piece of service, than out of respect to Don Gusman. Tell him I have sent an answer. Bid him read it upon your back.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: 'Tis but a very scurvy Character.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: If you think it is not writ plain enough, I'le try to mend it with a second Impression.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No Sir, It is all plain to be read, as Holy dayes in the Calender. It's in red Letters. Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Don Diego, I saw you from my window discoursing with Beatrice, and thence did conclude, that you knew my Father was abroad.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Yes Madam, I met him.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p:
Knowing you have ever been respectful to my Fathers Orders▪ and therefore wou'd not transgress them, how severe so ever, and that I could not invite you in, but with an absolute breach of my duty, I therefore came down to you, to let you know, that his severity and ill treatment of
you, has mov'd me to much concern for you; and has reviv'd in my heart the same kind sentiments it had before your provocations.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Is this to me Madam!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I had not so soon forgiven you, but by my kindness to make satisfaction for the injuries you receiv'd from his ruff retreatment last night.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Pray go on.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I have already endeavour'd to appease my fathers displeasure, and doubt not but e're night do induce him to revoke his prohibition.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Perfidious Woman, how customary is it for you to frame impostures, That are aforehand thus prepar'd with such notorious ones.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: The strangeness of your reply so much surprises me, I know not what answer to make on the sudden,

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Go ungrateful! Make answer to that Letter, which Don Gusman has sent you, and which you have not the pleasure to read, but after my perusal.

div.stage: Diego throws the Letter to her.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You amaze me yet more, take it up Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Far from the flattering Beat. Takes it up, Octa. reads whilst Diego talks. hopes you have given him of profiting by my misfortunes, I shall by his recieve advantage; since, I escape one so perfidious, that on the least occasion will sacrifice his interest to another, as you have done mine to him.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Beatrice, from whom came this note? who receiv'd it? and from whom?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Madam, I neither know the Messenger, nor him that sent it, and for that reason refus'd to receive it, and if he had not dealt so ill with the Messenger, 'tis probable he would have given an account from whom he brought it. I deny'd to take it, and Don Diego snatch'd it out of his hand.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Both the Mistress and the Servant act their parts most exactly well. For all that sereness of your countenance I perceive the disturbance in your mind, that artificial calm both in your looks and words is too thin a varnish to gloss over the perfidiousness of your heart.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Tho fierceness is usually inseparable from innocence▪ yet I will now constrain my self to wave it. And without passion tell you, that I have no pretenders besides Don Ruis and your self. This Don Gusman, whom you inform me sent this note, is a stranger, and one I never spoke to, never have I so much as seen him

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Do's not this Letter own a commerce betwixt you? do's he not say he follow'd your counsel? That he is your Lover, and my Rival?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Am not I to be credited sooner than a Letter without a name to't?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: We may constrain our selves not to believe great presumptions. But not to credit such convincing proofs is impossible. Therefore keep back the heart you come to restore, mine from this hour shakes off your bonds, and that you may not again enslave it, this day I will put it under the protection of one who is at least as fair as you, But questionless will not be so perfidious.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I doubt not but you may bestow your heart on a fairer person, but with all your precaution, you cannot make choice of one more faithful. But do not fondly believe I tell you this because I fear to lose you. I less concern my self to regain a place in your heart, than to discover the state of mine, which is well enough pleas'd not to discend to a justification.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: The mistery of the Cerenade and Letter is not so hard to unridle, as you woud make me believe by an absolute denyal of all: if you had said you knew of the Cerenade, but coud not help it, that you receiv'd his Love Letters but return'd no answer, that he made himself my Rival but had no encouragement, you had seem'd to disapprove what you had done by being willing to excuse it; but not to acknowledge any thing is to confess your self criminal in all, and this assurance which you discover in your obstinate disowning my accusations, shews the pleasure you have taken to offend me. Thus having made you sensible that I am not ignorant, nor you innocent, I'le leave you to sollace your self in the repose of your new conquest.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
Beatrice I perceive well enough that you hold intelligence
with Don Ruis, but in so critical a conjucture, I forbore to acknowledge it. Follow me up to my Chamber, and there resolve to make a full discovery or depart from me, and my eternal hatred be your stipend.

div.stage: Enter Don Gusman, Don Ruis, Elvira, Sanco, and Jacinta, out of the Church. Into the same street before Count Benev. house.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: How? In what manner did he beat you?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: In the best manner he coud, without doubt. The gallant person who diverted himself at my expence, made a shift to make my back, and his Cane meet some halfe a Score times.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: You told him you belong'd to me, and the offended Don Diego retains a grudge since our last quarrel, and consider'd thee accordingly.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No Sir, he told me that I belong'd to you, and without any consideration at all, loaded my back with his salutes, and sent me to you greeting—

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Are you sure you understood him right, did he name Don Gusman, and then say you belong'd to him.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I believe he took me for an arrant blockhead as you do, because he took such pains to beat it into me.—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: By his usage of Sanco and his Message, he takes you for his Rival.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Without doubt he takes him for his Rival, and it is as the most humble Vallet of his Rival, that I have been regal'd so plentifully.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: When you saw how he woud use you, you shou'd have told him from whom the note had come.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What had I gain'd by that, for besides that you had forbidden me. I shou'd only have changed my Master, not the imployment, and since I cou'd not escape beating, what matter was it for whose sake I had been beaten.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I will find time, to return Don Diego thanks, for his Message.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Since it was to his Rival that he meant the affront, it is I that am to take an account of his actions.

sp.speaker: Gu. s
sp.p:
I may be his en'my without being his Rival. He not
count to declare himself mine, has by his ill usage of one that he knew belong'd to me, has nam'd me for fear he shou'd doubt it, I stand in honour oblig'd to take notice of the affront.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I fear the event of this—

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: If I had not written the Note, Don Diego and you wou'd in probability never have had any more concern. Besides Sanco at that time belong'd not to you, but to me, since you were pleas'd to make me Master of him, and he was imploy'd in my business. So whether in concern of his Rival, or in consideration of his Master, he gave Sanco the beating, it is to me only that the affront was done,

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: It was an affront to both, therefore the best way to revenge it, is for one to set upon him before, whilest the other attaques him hehind.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: In my judgement you are both too nice to interpret an affront from a gentlemans ill treatment of a Servant, when the Master is not in presence. A Servants sawciness oftentimes deserves it.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I do not make a positive conclusion that I am oblig'd to resent it, but only supposing it an affront, that it concerns not Don Gusman, but me to revenge it.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I hope neither of you will think your selves so far concern'd as to heighten it to a quarrel.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Elvira, let not any such fears disquiet you. Don Gusman, how do you dispose of your self the rest of this morning?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I am now going to Court.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I'le wait on you thither▪ After I have conducted Elvira home.—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I will return into the Church, and pray Heaven to avert your minds from such resolutions

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Give me my Vail, now put on your own. Instead of the Church, I will go to Don Diego's house, and endeavour that way to prevent a quarrel, which else I see will follow, by my Brothers smoothing over his mind. Go Iacinta— Ring at his Door.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Signior, is Don Diego within.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I would speak with him, if he be at leasure.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: A Cavaliere is alwayes at leasure to receive the visits of the fair. Be pleas'd to walk in Madam.

div.stage: Enter Don Diego walking about in a fume. The Scene a Room in's House.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: False beyond thy Sex! In cunning more artificial than the most practiced of thy kind in Sin. Gods, shall my revenge persue her, or her Lover. Where shall it begin, or beginning, where must it end.

div.stage: Enter Ordgano, Elvira at a distance.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Sir, here is a fair Person come to give you a visit.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: If she be fair, she's faithless too.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: There, Madam, is my Master.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Don Diego, I desire the liberty to say something to you, that none shou'd be witness of, but my self.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Ordgano▪ quit the Room.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Stay, be pleas'd to command him too, that while I am with you to tell every body that shall come to visit you, that you are not within; for it much concerns me not to be surpris'd with you.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I charge you not to let any one come in, who ever it be: Go.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, the occasion of this visit, is to let you understand, that one action of yours this morning has procur'd you two enemies; both which have a design at your life, and either of them is brave enough to make you stand in need of all your valour.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I ghess the Enemies you mean are Don Ruis and Don Gusman.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The same Sir, tho the fate of arms shou'd give you advantage over one, yet you are not in safety, whilst the other has his blood to spill; and the second may do what the first faild in.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I neither doubt their courage nor my own. The most brave is not sure of success.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
To avoid the mischief, absent your self two or three dayes out of Town. In which time I will so qualifie things,
that there shall be no prejudice to your honour.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Quit the Town Madam for a quarrel! No.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: If the Love you have for the fair Octavia makes you find any difficulty in absence, let your servants onely give out you are gone some little journey: But especially let me beg the favour of you not to be seen to day.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I wish, with a blind obedience, I could acknowledge the honour you do me in the care you take of my safety. But far from avoiding my enemies, honour obliges me to prevent their inquiry by my presence.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Yes, had you a single enemy, but you have two?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: If Madam, for me you have this fear, I advise you to quit it. For the danger is not so great as you imagine, tho the odds be so. My enemies being valiant, they will without doubt be as generous.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: If your honour obliges you to accept the combat, the interest of your Mistress forbids it. Do you think she can approve of divulging so nice a secret, and if you love her as she deserves, wou'd it not be better to make a sacrifice of your fame to her, than to have the displeasure of exposing hers?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I should be much troubled, if it should cost me my own reputation to be sparing of anothers, whose interest I am no longer oblidg'd to. But if in obeying you, I shou'd be assur'd to do you a service; so pleasant a consideration, might make me forget what I owe my self.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Since neither the care of your self, nor the consideration of a person for whom you are oblig'd to have the greatest esteem in the world will induce you to comply. Know too, you will render me the greatest service imaginable. For as a secret I tell it you, that one of your two enemies is my Lover, the event of this quarrel must either way be unfortunate. If you conquer, death deprives me of him, if he vanquish you, I lose him in his flight.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: This is the real cause you require my absence?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: It is. Trust me with your honour a few dayes, and I will render it back bright as it is, with a full assurance of your safety.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p:
Your Love shall ever be a secret, but as to the rest, it
is impossible to give you an absolute satisfaction. All that I can do to serve you, is to constrain my resentment to Don Gusman for he (doubtless) is the gallant person, that has the honour to please you. I must not flie his presence, but at all times that he shall speak to me as a gallant person ought to do, he shall find, that I know in what manner to answer him.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Madam, let me first acquaint my Master. Speaks as they enter. I am strictly charg'd to the contrary.

div.stage: Octavia steps behind Diego▪ pulls down her Veil.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Whence is't, that Ordgano treats me to day after this strange manner? and that— Spies Octavia. I humbly beg your pardon Madam, I did not know that Don Diego was so agreeably taken up. I had not quarrel'd with his Servant, if I had known the ground of his Orders. I thought they had proceeded onely from the ill humour of his Master.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Do you Madam by way of reprisal, give me a visit to quarrel with me.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I came to clear your mistakes, and to tell you what I have learn'd of the Letter and Serenade. But at present you are not in a condition to hear me, and though you woud be in the humour to afford me your attention, I should not be so disobliging to interrupt the pleasure you receive with Madam— whose conversation questionless will be more charming, than any thing I have to say.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The compliment you make me wou'd be the beginning of a quarrel, if I should answer it in the same obliging manner. But I deceive my self, or the most agreeable one I can make you, is to quit the place, where you are not infinitely pleas'd to see me, I will Madam, and advise you not to discompose your Spirits, with imagining I intend to advantage my self by the divorce betwixt you and your Lover. Madam your Servant. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Madam, I'le wait on you down.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Well Madam, what is it you have to acquaint me with?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Nothing! but that you are very disobliging not to let me see the charming person to whom you have given the heart you found me not worthy of. If not out of good nature, you shou'd have don't for revenge, if she was fair, and I had seen that her beauty had justified her revolt, the sight must needs have rais'd a secret spight in my heart, I shou'd presently have fallen sick, and in a short time dy'd with grief for the loss of you. There had your revenge been compleated, Don Diego.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! Madam, that a person so witty as you believe your self, shou'd endeavour to get clear of a Treachery whereof you are convicted, by imputing one to me, of which there is so little appearance. I wish it was as easie for you to convince me, you never had a kindness for Don Gusman, as it for me to justifie, that I never yet have seen the face of that Lady you talk off.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: And Oh Heavens! Sir, for a man so witty as you believe your self too, to think you can perswade me out of my senses, why was your Sentinel set at door, contrary to your custome, but for fear of being surpris'd, which shews you were afraid of the presence of some body whom you were unwilling should see her. Why this precaution if the person was unknown to you?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I see, Madam, I was not to blame for asking you when you came in, if you were not come to quarrel, I find you are glad of any pretence that you make use of such a slight one.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: You woud not have foreseen that you shoud have been quarrell'd with, if you had not known your self guilty enough to occasion it. And but for your mistrustfulness I had not accus'd you of any thing.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: You wou'd not have wanted a pretence, tho you had found none; that came designedly for that purpose.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
I came thinking to do you a kindness. To tell you that Don Gusman was not the man that gave me the Cerenade. That the Letter, which put you into such a pelt, came from another. I wou'd have told you likewise the name of your Rival, whose gallantry last night clash'd with yours, and to have left you no scruple, I'de have told you too, who has been false to us both; how all this came about, and last of all, how I came to the discovery.
But since you have made a new conquest, the knowledge of this will be very indifferent to you, and I shall now spare my self the trouble.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: You may spare the labour Madam, if you think, as you your self said just now, to perswade me out of my senses. Was then the Cerenade last night, the servant this morning, and the Letter he brought, all but visions? Was you not follow'd from Church by Don Gusman's servant? Was it not the same person that brought the Letter? Were not the contents, that he follow'd your Counsel, that he was my Rival, and conjur'd you to hasten your promise? After this shall I not believe Don Gusman is the man? Shall all be Vision both by Night and by Day?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Answer me, Sir, I pray, to find a Lady in your Chamber, to force by a Sentinel, set to forbid entrance, to see you all confus'd at the surprise I gave you by pressing in; to hear your new Mistress talk of a divorce betwixt you and me, which was a secret, she cou'd not know, but from you alone; and lastly, to see you rather play the ridiculous person, then let slip any occasion to offend me, and to conduct a stranger down Stairs in the presence of one you knew, whom you left without the least civility of excuse.- answer me you that are so skilful in visions, if this be one, shall I be made believe that you know not this person, never saw her face, shall this pass for truth, or shall it all be vision, vision.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I have already told you, that the Lady you ground your anger on is an absolute stranger, that I have no manner of knowledge either of her name or person, I neither ask'd to see one, or hear the other.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
I have told you as much of Don Gusman, that I never had seen him, spoken to him, or receiv'd Letters from him, and yet you wou'd not believe me, tho you never found him in my Chamber. But Don Diego, after such evidences as I have receiv'd 〈◊〉 befits not a man of good sense so grosly to impose on a person that hath either eyes or ears. And you'd have done better to have said, that you cou'd not hinder a Lady so accomplish'd and beautiful, to have an inclination for you, that 'twou'd not have been like a gallant soul, to deny her entrance into your
house, when she came on purpose, to honour you with her visits. But that you receive them out of complaisance; that in your passion some words slipt from you of our falling out. But not to be willing to own any thing is to acknowledg your self guilty of all, and your obstinate denyal of your crime is a proof that you are not sorry for't. Adieu my Dear Lover, that has found a new Mistress full as fair, but questionless not half so false as the old, peaceably enjoy your new conquest and let there be no more Sentinels at your door, if I am the only person you are afraid off.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: So, now has fortune given her the run of the dice, she is march'd off as she thinks victorious, with an absolute belief that she has foyl'd me with my own weapon. Now will she conclude that she has all the reason of the World not to own any thing of her own crimes, unless I will acknowledge my self guilty of the like. And so stand in as much need of her pardon as she of mine. Thus she sells me at her pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Sir, there is a Gentleman without that woud not send in his Name desires to speak with you. But by his attendant it shou'd be Don Gusman, if Sanco bely'd not his Masters Name.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Wait him in. I believe the business he comes about, will suit well with my present temper.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Sir, I come to demand satisfaction for the affronts done me, I need not repeat more of 'em, then when I tell you, you took a Letter out of my servants hand by violence, broke it open and read it. Your usuage to him and your message to me you cannot have forgetton.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Enough— I own ev'ry tittle of your accusations! Now? Perfidious Woman wast thou but present, to hear Aside. thy obstinate denyals confuted by his own mouth. Sir, I am only sorry that you have so far gotten the start of me, to be the inviter. Now to tell my injuries woud be superfluous and loss of time. I will therefore with a ready complyance to your demand, wipe off as much as I can of my past remisness. Sir, I am ready to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: If we are seen together it may cause suspitions in some Persons, if they should meet us. Wherefore that nothing may hinder our design, nominate a place fit for such a rancountre, and we'l part at the door and go several wayes.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: At the Grove of Pines.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I know it, and will meet you there.

div.stage: Enter in the Street Don Gusman, Don Diego, Ordgano, Sanco.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Sanco return to Court, and stand in the Lobby, till you see Don Ruis coming by, tell him I accidentally lost his company, and urgent affairs prest me to be gone without allowing me time to take my leave.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: What makes thee look so pale and tremble?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I- I- got cold Sir last night with Serenadeing, and have a fit of an Ague, I think.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Go, go, walk it off.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Ordgano, Stir not from home till you hear from me, be diligent in your duty.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Country, Country.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ah Lord let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: What's the matter? you look as if you were not well, Country.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Oh, my heart akes.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: You tremble.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Woud not any one tremble at the wickedness that your Master and mine are gone about?

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: Why! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: After my Master went in, I had a Fools curiosity to hearken to their discourse, I laid my ear close to the door, and heard 'em talk a company of idle words. As injuries, grievances, affronts, and satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: They are gone to fight then.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Don Gusman all the way we came mutter'd the Devils Pater noster to himself.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: 'Tis so, their parting at door was but cunning.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay Lord, to see how cunning men are to go to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: I'le after 'em, but stay: whither is't they are gone?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: 'Twas to a Grove.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: The Grove of Pines.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay, ay, that.

sp.speaker: Ordg.
sp.p: I'le after 'em with all speed, and get some Friends along with me, to prevent their design.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay do, make haste and save a soul.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Ha, Sanco here! then I fear Don Gusman is gotten here before me upon the same design. Where's your Master?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Oh Sir I am glad you are come, he and Don Diego are gone to destroy both Soul and Body of one another.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I fear'd so, when I miss'd him in the Kings Lodgings, which way went they?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: To the Grove of Pines.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I'le endeavour to o'retake 'em.

div.stage: Exit. Ruis to the door. San. follows him talking

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I pray do Sir, and desire my Master, for the Lords sake, not to be kill'd, for if he dies I shall want a service. Methinks he shoud have a little care of himself for my sake. Well it is a strange thing, that men can't stay till Nature brings the right Keyes, but must wear such cursed Instruments at their Girdles to pick lock the doors of Mortality, and let Souls out so at randome.

lg.l: Who fight with swords for life sure care but little,
Since 'tis no more than this, in dock out nettle.

div.head: ACT. V.
SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene Octavia's Apartment in Count Benevent 's House.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: WOnder not, Madam, that the relation of this Quarrel gives me no more disquiet. Don Diego is a man so indifferent to me now, that I have no more than a common concern for his safety.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Can you then be content to see the life of a Lover remain expos'd to the fury of his enemies?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I cou'd not once have suffer'd it. But know Elvira, that perfidious man has had the arrogance to scan even the most innocent actions of my life to find pretensions to justifie his own disloyalty. This day, not two hours since, I surpriz'd him in his Chamber with a shameless woman, whom he preferr'd to me.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Time is now too precious to be trifl'd away in unprofitable grievances. Know, dear Friend, I was that woman you surpris'd. I went to acquaint him with the intentions of his enemies, and to perswade him to that, which I now press you to undertake, your interruption and his own obstinate gallantry rendred my indeavours ineffectual.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Have then my suspitions wrong'd him! And is he faithful still! Oh my friend, how subject are Lovers to mistakes?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: His innocence thus clear'd consent to use your interest to perswade him to grant that to a Mistress he refus'd to one unknown.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I'le rather let the worst happen fate has in store, than submit to visit him first. Try your interest, Madam, with Don Gusman.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
I confess, Madam, I have some ascendancy over him, and if I desire him to sacrifice his resentment to me, I believe he will not refuse it. But know my Brother and he are gone to Court, and tho I have sent Iacinta home with orders to watch their
return, and privately to acquaint Don Gusman, that I am at a Friends house, where I desire to speak with him, and to conduct him hither, yet I am afraid least they should attempt to find your Lover before they return home, to prevent that danger, you must condiscend to go immediately to Don Diego—

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: To go and visit him after the solemn leave I have taken, O, I cannot think on't.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.p: Madam, I have brought Don Gusman to the back door, where he waits for entrance.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Now, Madam, our design may be effected without the visit you are so unwilling to make.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! his coming hither is of dangerous consequence. He is the man of whom Don Diego is become jealous, and if he should know, that I have seen him here, he wou'd have reason to believe, that I have indeed betraid him.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: To take away your fear, you shall understand how I contriv'd it. I order'd Iacinta to conduct him to the back door of your house, without giving him any account to whom it belong'd, tho he should make inquiry. Now let some one go down, and open the back door, and bring him up the private stair case, into your apartment, I alone will appear to receive him; thus it will be so far from coming to the knowledge of Don Diego, that Don Gusman himself will never know that he has been here in your House.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: But if my Father should come whilst you are speaking with Don Gusman, I'le assure you; and suspect me to be half at least concern'd in some amorous intrigue. I assure you, he is a man the hardest of any in the world to be put off with excuses.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Let but the back door he enters at still remain unlock'd, and if it should so happen, that your Father returns, he may slip down the back stairs, and go out unseen.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Go then Iacinta, bid Beatrice unlock the back door, and do you conduct him up the little stairs. Madam, Exit Ja. I conjure you not to protract his stay with any unnecessary discourse; but to hasten his retreat with all expedition imaginable.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: After a few minutes discourse, I will release you from your fears.

sp.speaker: Octa
sp.p: I will conceal my self in this little withdrawing-Room, during the time of his stay. I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Don Gusman, I have contriv'd this meeting to satisfie my self of your intentions, and if you own that I have any power over you▪ do not disguise 'em. Do you still retain your resolution to fight Don Diego.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: That is already done: and he is now no more either my enemy or your Brothers.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O Heavens! is he dead?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: No Madam, he is not dead.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Is he hurt, or wounded, O my fears!

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I will not inquire the cause, Madam, of your concern, but certainly he must be either a Lover or a Brother, and either of those Titles are sufficient to justifie your exacting from me an account of what is pass'd.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Quickly Sir let us hear—

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Don Diego, and my self, being gotten into the field, we had already our swords in our hands, and just ready to engage, when Don Ruis, who persu'd us with all speed, interpos'd and declar'd to Don Diego that I was not his enemy, but that he was the only man offended, and was able without my assistance to take his revenge. Don Diego might perhaps have hearken'd to what he said; but I urg'd that he cou'd not quit me for another, without confessing himself conquer'd. He cou'd not digest so harsh a word, yet the obstinate Don Ruis to prevent our engagement, put himself again betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What will be event of this?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Whilst we were thus contending, some friends, who had likewise heard of our design, I know not how, came to us, and woud know the ground of our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: This happy circumstance lightens my heart of half it's fears.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p:
Don Diego, forc'd by their importunity to tell the cause of his resentment, declar'd he was jealous of me, charging me of attempts to deprive him of the affections of a Lady, for whom he had an ardour that was inextinguishable, then mention'd a Serenade last night, and a Letter that this morning he surpriz'd
in the hands of my servant. But Don Ruis clear'd me of these accusations owning himself the person that gave this Cerenade, and that sent the Letter too, but not to the Lady, but her servant. Don Diego perceiving his errors, embrac'd me in the most obliging manner, and made excuses, which I receiv'd with a sincere affection.

sp.speaker: Octavia.
sp.p: Now my hopes blossom a pace?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Now to adjust matters betwixt him and Don Ruis, their friends affirmed, that the extroardinary beauty of a Lady might justifie both their pretensions to adore her. That two such Gallant persons, coveting the same object, declar'd it to be of a more then common value. And that a Lover without Rivals might conclude he had a Mistress without merit.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Now Madam, comes the result of all—

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: By these discreet Mediators they were oblig'd to conjure the fair person that charm'd them both to decide their right by her choice. And to promise one another, to look upon him without envy, whom it shoud please her to make happy, since both of them could not be so. Thus Madam, whether I speak to the Sister, or the Mistress—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: O Madam, your Father unluckily is come in at the back door, and finding it open is so enrag'd that he has lock'd it and taken away the Key.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Haste then and conduct this Gentleman down the Fore-Stairs, and let him out at the great Door, Sir, shall I beg your pardon.—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis impossible your Father follow's me close and is by this time at the very Door.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I hear him.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Run, run in there Sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Hey! Where are you, Ods precious no body below, all got to the house top like Cats in a Moonshiny night. Octavia, where are you? Ods precious Octavia who unlock'd the back door, how comes it open, Ods precious have not I commanded it should eternally be kept shut.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: It was was open'd, Sir, but just now.—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious that now should have been never. How often have you heard me say, That the back door, lets in the Theif, and lets out the Whore.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, having made a visit just behind your house, and not being willing to come so near, without giving Madam Octavia an assurance of my respects, I sent to desire her, that the back door might be open'd to save me the trouble of going round.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, Madam Elvira, I beg your pardon most heartily. Ods precious I thought no more of you than of the Soul of King Philip.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I am much displeas'd with my self for the liberty I have taken, since it is so much against your will.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious talk no more on't, I am extreamly glad of he honour you do me in visiting my daughter.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I hope Sir you will pardon my presumption.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious Madam, I'de a pull'd down one side of my house to have let you in.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The goodness you have so readily to excuse it—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious no more words about nothing, I am old and hasty, but true and hearty, and Alphonso is my name. But Ods precious Octavia, you have been to blame for entertaining this good Lady here all this while, when you have there so much a pleasanter and cooler Room. Come, Madam within there are some Pictures, and other little curiosities to please your Fancy.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, we are but just come out thence, I have taken a full view of all. 'Tis indeed a very fine place.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But Ods precious whilst you do stay—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I was just taking my leave as you came in.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious but now I am come you'l stay a little longer.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, I humbly beg your pardon, because I should commit a great incivility to some Ladies of the Court, who sent to know at what hour I would be at leasure to receive their visit, and it is now near the time appointed.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Nay, ods precious I have nothing to say against punctilio's;
if it be so, do as like's you, and live the longer. Free-will and hearts ease make a complexion beyond Red-Wool and Fucus.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, yor servant—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Nay, Ods precious, but I'le wait on you home.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: By no means Sir, I will not give you that trouble. Madam, your Servant.

div.stage: They kiss on both cheeks, the whilst Octa. speaks to Elv.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O dear Elvira refuse not my Fathers offer, Aside to Elvira. his absence at this time will infinitely oblige me. Since Madam, you know my Father offers nothing but what is requisite, why? is't, you do yourself the injury to refuse it.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I deny'd my self the honour, cautious of being the occasion of too great a trouble.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, Madam, I am not so old yet to think it a trouble to wait upon Ladies. Mine was not an age of that debauchery to make men old and decrepid at thirty. I am upwards of threescore, and yet, Ods precious, I am sound of Limb and cheary of heart. Ha, come Lady.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Your servant.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Madam, your servant, Ben. Elv. Beatrice. exeunt. Beatrice make haste up again. Sir, you may now venture to come forth again. You narrowly escap'd, being discover'd.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I heard ev'ry word he said, and wonder'd what prevention you coud find.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I was all in a trembling, fear left me no power to speak, I was hasty to say something, but knew not what?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Madam Elvira brought it off very handsomly.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: She was a great presence of wit, and speaks with much assurance. I wonder Beatrice stayes.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: May I yet venter down stairs, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Stay Sir, and I will look out at Window she goes to the window, returns. and see if my Father is gotten into the Street, Oh Heavens, Sir, I see Don Diego below contending with Beatrice to come in.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Madam, from him.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
Nothing never happ'n'd so unluckily. I hear him coming
up stairs, he is rush'd in, in spight of her, retire in there again Sir, and shut the door.

div.stage: Enter Beatrice. Don Diego pressing in.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Nay Sir, you must not, pray Don Diego retire, My Lady will be angry.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Nay Beatrice, I have proof enough thou art not my friend. Madam, I know you are already so much offended, that I cannot increase your anger with any new guilt; therefore I have prest into your house, but this is the most warrantable crime man ever committed; since it is to cast my self at your feet and supplicate your pardon for all my pass'd offences. I am now convinc'd of all: How much I have wrong'd your Virtue. I bless the day, the hour, that has render'd you innocent, and me only guilty.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Rise Sir, I pardon you—

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Are you so heavenly, have you such a stock of mercy to forgive me?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I do Sir, with all my heart. But now you must be gone. My father has forbidden you the house, and charg'd me never to receive you more. He will presently come in if he finds you here, neither you nor I must hope his pardon.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Whilst I was watching below to be blest with a sight of you from your Windows, he came forth in company of a person, whom 'tis probable he will not so soon leave. If with as much sincerity as speed, you granted my pardon, you will have time more than necessary to give me farther assurances of it, and I too shall have enough to return you thanks for your favours.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I have already said it, and confirm'd it, and most willingly again repeat it, I do pardon you, with all my heart I do; but now Sir you must go.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I fear to forgive so many injuries with so much readiness; is less a mark of your goodness than of your indifference.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Sir, what woud you have me say?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I woud be assur'd that I owe my pardon to your bounty and goodness only, and not to your fears or desires to have me gone.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
If you think that you do not deserve the favours I bestow
on you, now merit it by granting that which I demand of you, Not to stay any Longer. Your presence gives me much disquiet, from which I beg that by your sudden absence you'd deliver me.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Your earnestness to have me gone, gives me suspitions That you design not my pardon, but my banishment.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: To leave you no reply, know that what ever offence you have been guilty of, to refuse believing that I now forget it, is to be guilty of a much greater.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: But Madam, all that you have done for me is unprofitable, if you do not yet more. Don Ruis with whom I have been quarrelling in the field, disputes with me the honour of serving you, and to reconcile us, some friends have prevail'd with us, to submit our selves to your choice; as soon as you have pronounc'd it, the unfortunate is to bear his wretchedness without a murmur, and I have so highly offended you; that I cannot but fear I am the person that must be miserable.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I will engage my word to prefer you to Don Ruis, you never was so dear to me as now, therefore, Sir, fear nothing, or only fear, if you depart not now I desire it, that I'le thrust you out a door.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: How mighty pressing you are Madam! You must have an aversion for me that my presence gives you so great an affliction

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O Sir, my Father.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: If he shoud come! The back door.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: O Sir, he has got the Key of't, be gone, be gone, or all my spight, and malice will return.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Let but me stay one moment longer, that in your eyes I may once more find the way to your heart.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Oh Madam, looking out at the window, I saw your Father meet with Don Ruis, and has deliver'd Madam Elvira into his hand, and is return'd, he is just at the door.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: We are undone—

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I'le make sure of my retreat in here?

div.stage: Don Dieg. runs to the door of the withdrawing-room. Half opens the door, puts one leg in, Octavia catches hold of his other arm to pull him back.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p:
Hold you must not Sir, my Father will come in there immediately, that being the coolest Room
in the house, he alwayes writes his Letters there, and order'd when he went out, that Pen, ink, and paper should be carried in ready against his return.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Lock it and say you have lost the Key, say any thing.

div.stage: Goes half way in and retreats.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Hold Sir, forbear, there is no lock to the door.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I now discover ungrateful woman, what oblig'd you to be so earnest with me to be gone—

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Go, look in, and see one at the further end of the Room stand wrapt and twin'd in the window Curtain, a pair of large feet are visible, I know 'tis a Lyon by his Paw. I'le say no more to you now, because I am forc'd to leave you, but had I as little honesty as your self, I should now acquaint your Father—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Sir, come this way, go down these little stairs to the back door, and remain there till I give you notice of an opportunity to make your escape.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Beatrice this is most unfortunate. What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I heard my Master unlock his Study door. Madam go down, and pretend something of business, and all the while you discourse, keep your body betwixt the door and him, or find some occasion to shut it. I'le place Don Gusman at the top of the stairs in readiness to slip down at a minutes warning.

sp.speaker: Octa
sp.p: Do Beatrice, I'le run down before, for fear he should be coming out, and frame some pretence to keep him longer there.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Sir, Pray come forth. Enter Don Gusman.
O Sir Don Diego saw you for all the Curtain.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Did he know who I was?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No Sir, I believe not, he only discover'd by your feet that you were a man, follow me Sir to the stair head.

div.stage: Enter Don Diego. Peeping into the Room, and enters by degrees.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p:
Ha, I see no body, all's quiet, I hear no noise in any part of the House, this was, as I suspected, all but design, they were urgent with me to be gone, for fear I should make a discovery of the person they conceal'd, the pretence too of the old Counts being return'd was a false alarm to draw me out of the Room, till they conveyed the other away. 'Tis so, here's no
body now. O my too tender sense of her honour? O Female subtilty? had I but suspected this before I woud have forc'd that traytor from his Sanctuary into the open field, and there have reveng'd my injuries with my Sword, I hear some body coming up I'le step in till I know who it is.

div.stage: Dieg. goes into the room, where Gusman came out.
Enter Octavia, Beatrice, following her at a distance.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Beatrice, I have got the Key of the Back door. My Father had laid it down upon the little table in his study, run, run down, and let Don Diego out, that I may carry't again before he misses it. Oh Heavens! She has not yet Beat. Exit. the backway convey'd Don Gusman out, he is still in the next Room, I saw him put to the door: I thought you had been gone, for Heavens sake Don Gusman keep close till the jealous Don Diego.—

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Well Madam.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Ah.—

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: What woud you say of the jealous Don Diego? what think you now has not his suspitions wrong'd your virtue, has he not been much to blame, for doubting a fidelity so pure? And you have questionless been very obliging, to have so much goodness for a man who deserv'd it so little. O ungrateful, and perfidious!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: O he's here!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Speak lower Sir, or you will undo us both. You are again in a mistake—

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: In a mistake deceitful Woman!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: For Heaven sake, Sir, speak lower or my Father.—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, who's here?

sp.speaker: Octa. Beat.
sp.p: Ah, Ah.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, Don Diego, I thought I had forwarn'd you my house. You Mistress Minx, Ods precious, was that the design of your coming down to steal away the Key, to let him out, thy blood shall wash away the stain from thy Family when I have been reveng'd of this Traytor, this Theif that steals into my house, and robs me of my honour. Ods precious, Sir, you are come a visiting. I'le give you, your entertainment.

sp.speaker: Oct. Beat.
sp.p: Ah, Ah-

div.stage: Oct. Bea. runs down the back stairs, exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Are you got to the door? Don Dieg. fights only warding the blows, and defending himself, and retreats to the door. Fighting, exeunt. I'le wait on you down. Ho Pedro, Pedro, shut the door Pedro.

div.stage: Enter Don Gusman. The Scene changes to the Street.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Don Diego has not yet made his escape▪ I would fain meet him at his coming out, to search into his temper and resolutions.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Give me my vail Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Madam, here's Don Gusman.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: O Sir, my Father has surpriz'd Don Diego in the house, we left 'em with their swords drawn. He threatned to murder me. But I took the opportunity to make my escape at the back door whilst they quarrel'd. Don Diego knows it was you that were in the closet.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Whither do you fly Madam?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I know not Sir, to Elvira.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: She and her Woman pass'd by just now, and Don Ruis presently after.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I must take shelter quickly, I shall be persu'd.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Are you well acquainted with Don Ruis his house?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Take this Key then and go into the apartment forwards, whilst I go and see how the business ends between your Father and your Lover. Of which I'le bring you word presently.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Pray do Sir, and satisfie 'em both in what you know of the business. Come Beatrice.

div.stage: As Don Gusman is going off he meets Don Diego.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Don Gusman you are the Person of the World I desired to meet. Now at least, I hope, we may pretend a just ground to quarrel

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Hold Sir, when I fight it is in the field.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: Lets go then.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Stay Sir and hear me, you will but put your self to an unnecessary trouble.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Don Gusman I expect to find you of a temper not to disown, but justifie your actions.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: It is Sir, and I shall both own and justifie my being in the House of the Count de Benevent.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Enough Sir, Come.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Stay Sir, and let me tell you in short, That I was no sooner return'd from the field, but I was inform'd by the Servant of Elvira, that her Mistress was gone to a Friends House, and had given her order to bring me to her with all speed, where she had an opportunity to discourse with me, which the presence of Don Ruis allow'd her not at home. I went: was conducted in a back way at a private door: was had up into a fair apartment, where I was received only by the fair Elvira, her first words demanded if I were resolv'd to fight with you. I replied we had already been in the field, and that you was no longer my enemy or her Brothers. Those doubtful words deceiv'd the understanding of one that hearken'd, for then a Lady bolted out of an inner Room, eagerly demanding if you was kill'd! Her passionate enquiries forc'd from me a speedy relation of what had pass'd in the field, which scarce was ended when news was brought that her Father was come in; that he had lock'd the back door, which was left open for my retreat; to avoid his presence, I retired into an inner Room, but he no sooner enter'd, but Elvira took her leave to be gone, he offer'd her his service home, which she accepted to give me an opportunity to get out of the house. They were no sooner gone, but your coming up occasioned a second surprise. I again made my retreat to the same place. What follow'd I need not tell you. Now Don Diego do you think, you and I have any occasion to go into the Field.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: How malitiously fate contrives to turn the respects and services I pay to that person I love, into occasions of hatred and displeasure.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Love to your advantage will soon o'recome those resentments.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: My follies have expos'd her to the fury of an enrag'd Father. All his wild anger now will flash on her.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: She is not in his power: whilst you two were contending she made her escape. Here I had the fortune to meet her, we but just parted as you came.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: And whither is she fled for Refuge?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I have given her the Key of my apartment, where if Elvira is from home she will do me the honour to stay till my return.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: You have remov'd a world of care and trouble from my heart.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: She gave me her commands to make enquiry what has happ'n'd to her Father and you in this quarrel.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I retreated, onely defending my self till I reach'd the stairs, and then I was too nimble for the old assaylant. He persu'd me down, with what speed he cou'd, but I first made sure of the door, and in a minute, when it was just going to be lock'd by one of his servants, and so made my escape without doing or receiving any hurt. Come Don Gusman, let me not delay throwing my self at her feet, to implore her grace and favour, and from her breast remove the anxiety of her fears.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Leave that to my care. I counsel you to go directly to some friends that you know have the greatest influence o're her offended Father, and by their assistance disabuse him if he think any thing has pass'd betwixt you and Octavia in prejudice to his honour, and her virtue.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: I approve of your advice. During my absence, excuse my extravagancies and prepare me a kind reception.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I promise you the best of my service.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Friend, if any but your Master come to enquire for me, say I am not here?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If they ask for you, by your name, I may safely say I Don't know where you are: but if they enquire for one with no name, how then?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Why then say the same—

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: So I will, if your Lady desires the same.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Do honest friend?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Living in the Service of a Cavaliere, you cannot but be so well bred, as to have at all times an excuse ready to serve a Lady.

sp.speaker: San,
sp.p: Yes, I'le tell a Lye to shew my breeding.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Now Beatrice go with all speed to my Aunts house, acquaint her with these unlucky accidents, and tell her I desire leave to put my self under her protection, that during the time of my Fathers displeasure, she may be responsible for my carriage. Say I am at present with Madam, Elvira.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yes, Madam?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Stay Beatrice, first give me the Key of the door, I'le lock my self in, and make answer to no body, 'till your return, except Don Gusman; as you go down charge Sanco to watch his Masters coming, and to bid him speak, when he knocks at the Door, that I may be sure not to open it to any one but him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Madam, he is come already—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Go then Beatrice, make haste.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Madam, I bring you the good news that your Father and Lover parted without the least damage receiv'd from eithers Sword. And that Don Diego is gone to get friends to mitigate his displeasure, by giving him a just account of his being in the house and—

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Hold, hold Madam, I'le first see if my Master says he is within. Sir, here's a Lady urgent to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: I'le not be seen—

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Step into that Closet, Madam, and shut the door, your imprisonment shall be but short. Entreat the Lady to walk in.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: As far as I see she wants no entreaty, Madam, my Master is within as good luck will have 't.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I knew that, I almost overtook him at the Door. You see Sir, I am as good as my word, I told you, you should see me when it was convenient.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: How egregiously. I have been mistaken; till now I thought that, Octavia, and this unknown had been the same person.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Whence is it Sir, you seem amaz'd?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: If Elvira shoud know I converse with this invisible Mistress, she woud suspect me false, and punish the treachery by renouncing my Love.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Do's my presence Sir, displease you, that you thus coldly receive this favour, which I coud not grant without giving my self so much confusion.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p:
'Tis true Madam, that you did promise to honour me with your presence, and when you had the goodness to make it, your words had something in 'em very harmonious, but now the fear I have, least any shoud surprise you here, lets me not see
you without great reluctance, therefore, if you will sensibly oblige me, deprive me of the honour I confess my self unworthy of.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: How pleas'd I am to hear this. Aside Don Gusman, I thought the answer you return'd in writing, had been but rallery, or if meant really, that you writ it injustice to your friend; whose Mistress you suspected me. I came now with resolutions to convince you of that mistake, by unvailing my self to you. But since I find how little satisfi'd you are with my visit, I assure you, I will never more do you the honour to trouble you. Fare you well Sir.

div.stage: Elvira goes out at door, comes running in.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: At what Madam, are you surpris'd?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Some one is coming up stairs— to her self. it is my Brother. I'le run into the Closet. Ha, there is a Woman, I saw her Elvira runs to the Closet, pulls the Door a little open, Octa. within, claps it too again. hand, when she clapt the Door against me. I find 'tis not out of respect to thee Elvira he has seen, that he refuses the kindness of Elvira vail'd. But for her sake that is there conceal'd.

div.stage: Enter Ruis, Ruis speaks to Elvira taking her for Octavia, she all the while shifts from him.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Madam, I have heard of the misfortunes that happ'n'd at Count Benevents; and came with all possible haste to offer you my service. Were not your interest concern'd, I shoud rejoyce at the accident that gives me opportunity to converse with the person, for whose society alone I woud quit the rest of the World. Why is it Madam, that you fly from me? What do you fear from a Lover that never oppos'd your rigour but by a Multitude of respects? And who having heard of your disasters, does not approach you, but to make an offer of all the services he is capable to render?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: To whom, Don Ruis, do you beleive you speak?

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: To Octavia, who has escap'd from her Fathers house, and came to my sister Elvira, but not finding her within, has given you the honour of her company.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I know not who has so inform'd you. But the Lady you see is so far from being Octavia, that she is not in the least known to you.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Don Gusman you are questionless so much my friend, as not to make a mistery of a thing I know so well; if the fair ungrateful, to whom I coud never render my self considerable enough to be belov'd, had not cruelly desir'd you to do it. She woud not hide her self as she does, if in my place, Don Diego had come and assur'd her of his service, and this her refusal to answer, is not the first injustice she has done me.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Don Ruis to oblige you to retire, I'le confess to you, that this is the unknown charming person I told you of; therefore let me entreat you not to do her the affront to endeavour to know her better.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Ah Don Gusman, you interress your self too much to my disadvantage; I know this to be Octavia, I had a relation of what pass'd in her fathers house, with an account of her escape and being here, from Beatrice her own servant, whom I met as she was going to the Ladies Aunt.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Whatever she told you, yet I assure you, that you are now mistaken: and affirm that this is not Octavia, but the vail'd Lady.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: If what you say be true, and that the person I see is not Octavia, let her tell me so her self, and I'le withdraw; I do not demand the sight of her, since she is unwilling to be seen, but one word is quickly spoke, and I am resolv'd not to retire til from her own mouth. I receive my adieu.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Two or three words Madam, will deliver us from his presence. I do not say in what a fear I am for you, and for my self, if it should happen that others should surprise you here: do not stay for the misfortunes which I foresee, since with one word you may have free passage Gusman speaks this aside to Elvira. and rescue me from a mighty trouble.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: See Sir, if I can rescue

div.stage: Elvira turns her back to Ruis, lifts up her vail, and shews Gusman her face.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Hau! conceal your face again, Madam, and be resolute neither to speak a word, nor let him see you, I expect to Elvira. Don Diego will come presently and ask for Octavia, who is in the Closet, into which I will put you as soon as your Brother is gone out of the Room. Don Ruis I turns to Ruis. can't prevail with the Lady to speak one word to you

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, here's Don Diego below, shall I fetch your Pistols out of the Closet?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Hold Sirrah, what woud you have the Pistols for?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: O Sir, now 'tis a rare time to be reveng'd as he comes up stairs, they are ready charg'd.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Go and wait on him up—

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: If I was a person of Quality, and he shoud beat my servant, but half so much as he did yours, I'de shoot at him tho there were no more men in the World.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Hold your prating, unless you have a mind to be beaten again.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nay Sir, he has disparag'd your Livery enough already with his Cane, I am almost a sham'd to walk after you in't; there remains the print of every blow he gave me visible to all the world to your disgrace.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: If you are my servant, hold your tongue and do your duty.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I know not well whither I am your servant or not. This is your coat, but I have been looking under't, and there I find I wear the Livery of Don Diego, black and blew upon Orenge-Tawny. And he takes the liberty to beat me at his pleasure, as if he was my master.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: I'le run my sword in your Guts.

div.stage: Gusman makes an offer to draw his Sword, San. takes a large leap to the door.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Oh, Don Diego's here Sir.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: My obliging enemy, I have staid longer than I expected. Octavia, who makes your apartment her sanctuary, and who already has so much reason to hate me, will be offended at it without question But Madam, I hope you will give me your pardon, when you shall know that I have spent my time wholly in your service, visiting of friends who have power with your father, to try if they can pacifie his displeasure, and make him favourable to my desires.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Now Don Gusman, will you affirm that this vail'd person is not Octavia, how can you excuse the wrong to friendship, and the injuries done to me?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p:
'Tis I who have reason to be offended, that find you
here Don Gusman who gave me his word to serve me, has not been punctual to his promise, to give you opportunity in my absence to insinuate into the affections of that beauty who has charm'd us both.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: You are much to blame Don Diego, for making any complaints against me; far from embracing the interest of Don Ruis I have protested to him, e're since he came, that this Lady was not Octavia, as he believ'd: but since you are both present, I am not any longer oblig'd to deny that it is she her self. If you are minded to have her away, behold I deliver her into your hand, for I know from her own mouth, that it was you she resolv'd to make her choice.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: He must take my life that will take her from hence, before she has told me her self, that it is you whose service she is pleas'd to accept. Don Gusman whom I thought my friend, does not give me marks enough of it, to oblige me to relie upon his word. I will stand to the conditions we have made. I doubt whether Octavia will be for you, or me, so long as she does not say any thing:

div.stage: Enter Octavia out of the Closet.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: If there wants only my speaking, you shall not be long in doubt.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Ruis. Ha.—

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: If my esteem can do you any good, that I offer you; but it is impossible for me ever to give you my Love: bestow your heart on some other person, whose inclinations may make her worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: The fatal sentence now is pass'd, my hopes as the Sun goes down in Clouds, now set in dark despair. But nere like that to rise again.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Endeavour not to take ill what I have said to you, since it was you only forc'd me to say to much.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: No Madam, now I withdraw all my pretensions; no more do I obstruct your course of Love. As she and you think fit, dispose of her.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Now Sir, convey me secretly to my Aunts, under whose care and 〈◊〉 you shall leave me, till from your friends you have an account of my Fathers temper and resolutions. I will no longer 〈◊〉 the return of Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Ho?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Run down and get two Chairs ready. to Elvira. aside. Madam I'le send you away in one.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Now friend I find you told me nothing but truth. That Lady is not Octavia, Madam, I beg your pardon, you see how much it did concern me to enquire.

div.stage: A noise without, and squeaking of Women.
Enter Octavia running, bolts her self into the Closet, Elvira comes running at the door, her vail hangs, she loses it, she runs to the Closet, finds it lock'd.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I find the Ladies and I are of the same constitution, sworn enemi's to drawn Swords.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The door is shut, Elvira runs to get up her vail, meets Ruis who had taken it up. what shall I do.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nay if you are all providing for Sanco creeps under the Table. yourselves, I'le shift for one.

div.stage: Enter Ruis, Gusman, Diego Alguazil, Count de Benevent, and officers.
Ruis takes up the vail as he comes in.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Don Diego, you are my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Sir I submit.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, hold him fast—

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Madam, here's your vail.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Come Ods precious, where are you gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: Ha Elvira!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, that's none of her.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: O disgraceful Maid, was it you that kept your self so close in your vail, and stood so mute, shame to thy sex, and dishonour to thy Family. I'le be reveng'd. Ruis. lays hand on his Sword.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Hold Don Ruis.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Hold Sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious, she has been playing pranks too? The Moon's in the critical minute.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I will at present choak my anger,—

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: By all that's sacred in friendship, I swear that nothing has pass'd betwixt your fair sister and 〈◊〉 the most austere vertue can disapprove—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ay, ay, no harm, no harm, Ods precious my jewel will be at that too anon.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: 'Till you prest her to speak, I did not so much as know the person I had been conversing with to be Elvira.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Come, come, Ods precious where is her fellow Comrade in mischief? Ods precious there's never any good towards, when young Girles get together a tatling.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Don Diego by order of Justice you must remain my Prisoner, unless you consent to marry the Lady. No other Act of yours can vindicate her fame, or restore to her Family the honour you have taken from it.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Do you, Count Benevent, exact this from me?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious do I.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: You seek to force a blessing on me, which I would have implor'd from you, and have already imploy'd my best friends to interceed for.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious then I am satisfied as to that punctilio: But Ods precious, where is she? where is she?

div.stage: Enter Octavia. She coms out of the Closet.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: I may now venture out, and appear unveild. Sir with my face uncover'd, I kneel before you to let you see I have not a heart conscious of crimes to make me blush. I know not of any offence I have committed, except my fear of your displeasure be one. I fled not Sir from you, but from your Anger.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious that's all one: I'le march you off for all that. There take her: look to her your self, Ods precious you know her tricks better than I do.

div.stage: Ben. gives Octavia to Don Diego.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.p: Now Sir, I hope, your anger is appeas'd, and you are fully satisfied.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious I have no more to say.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: But Don Ruis, I perceive your brow is still contracted. If my acknowledgements can remove your displeasure, I will confess that no Lover ever sacrific'd a heart in brighter flames, than I do mine to the fair Elvira. Nor is the offering, I believe, displeasing to her: If, Don Ruis, you hold me worthy of your sister, and my friendship is as acceptable to you, as my love to her, promote it's perfection; and let our marriage bind me to you in a stricter union.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Ods precious e'ne let him have her too. As they have been Rogues together, e'ne let 'em fare both alike, and now
go to be married together. Ods precious, it is the best way, so a done.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I feel the torments of successless love, and cannot be so cruel to see my friend in that condition. 'Tis my only happiness at this time, that I can so well dispose of her. I have a mind at present so disturb'd at my own loss, that I have no conduct o're my self, how unfit am I then to have the charge of another? Here Sir, I resign her to you.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.p: So, Now the danger is pass'd and the storm is quite over, I'le venture abroad and bid adieu to my Cover.

div.stage: Sanco crawls from under the Table.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I wish, in return, I could settle such a peace in your breast, as you have done in mine.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ods precious Cheary, cheary, Don Ruis, Love in the breast is like a bush of dry Thorns in an oven; it blazes, and crackles, and keeps a sputter for a while, but presently gives over. Ods precious think no more of her.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir the next time you ask my Master leave to send me to be beaten, pray let it be to gain your Mistress, now he goes away with her, I have been cudgel'd to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Ruis.
sp.p: I cannot soon forget the ruin of my hopes, but I will wear my sorrows with discretion.

lg.l: Yet if my griefs by fits you do discover,
Excuse those starts in a rejected Lover.

div.head: EPOLOGVE.
div.l: OUr Play's success we very much do fear,
For we see few, but Wits and Criticks here▪
We are sure of you at all times of th' year.
Our Londoners are gone for recreation
To spend with Country friends the long vacation;
Or else to Epsome for a moneth's purgation.
The Country gallants too, whom suits of Law,
And Four Cart-horses up to Town did draw
In mouldy Couch, fill'd with their she relations,
Who once a year come up to see the fashions;
When each had bought her a new tawdry Gown,
The Law Suits ended and the terms were done.
They and their Sun burnt Squires hasten'd down.
How we rejoc'd to see 'em in our pit!
What difference, me thoughts there was,
Betwixt a Country Gallant and a Wit.
When you did order Perriwig with Comb,
They only us'd four fingers and a Thumb.
Whil'st you stroak'd up fring'd gloves were elbow deep,
They one glove on, the other off did keep,
Thus twist and twist, and the tand calve-skin gripe,
Till it look'd like a Chitterlin or Tripe;
And then to stretch it, thus thro' hand they'd pull it.
But Lord! the wisp'd Cravat that hung below the gullet!
How pale and white did your complexions shew
To their Mary-Gold-Faces, as they sat by you!
But when betwixt the acts they did stand up,
Their swords look'd as if they belong to th'County troop▪
Huge ones they wore in narrow girdle Belts.
But most I laugh'd to see their flapping Felts.
They in their greasie waste Belts and great Swords,
Like Yeomen look'd, but, you like any Lords.
You had large shoulder Belts with Riband ty'd,
And each a little little spit-frog by his side.
Well as you please you may laugh on and jeer,
But such as these all your Forefathers were.
Tho they perha●●●n't so much Wit as you,
They've more 〈…〉 and more Money too;
But there the 〈◊〉 does them out do.
Wherefore your Company our stage renounces,
For the kind Country clowns, and the rich City Dunces.
